SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw the notice of motion standing in my name for the disallowance of the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991, No. 4. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that on 14 March I reported to the Senate on the concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances with this instrument. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, has since undertaken to take the Committee's concern into consideration when fresh regulations are made within the next month or so. The Committee is grateful for this cooperation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the correspondence of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
11 March 1991
The Hon John Kerin MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Regulations, Statutory Rules 1991 No. 4, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 7 March 1991.

Regulation 11 provides a penalty for a person who fails to make certain records and prepare accounts. Other provisions in the Regulations require the payment of levies and charges (r.3), require a person to give the Secretary information (r.7, 8, 9) and require a statement to be given to the processor (r.10). The penalty in r.11 does not appear to attach to these provisions. Your advice would be appreciated as to whether there is intended to be a penalty for breach of these provisions. In particular, could you advise whether there is a penalty for failure to pay the levies or charges, which is revenue owing to the Commonwealth or to its instrumentalities.

The Committee appreciates that penalties may exist for these offences elsewhere, such as in the parent Act or some other Act. In such cases the Committee believes that penalties should be clearly set out in the Explanatory Statement. It is, however, preferable if all penalties could be set out in the instrument itself. In any event, it would appear to be a breach of personal liberties if penalty provisions are included in delegated legislation with no indication to those affected of what those penalties are.
Your advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
Thank you for your letter of 11 March 1991 concerning the penalties applying to breaches of the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Regulations (Statutory Rules 1991 No 4).
The penalties relating to breaches of Regulations 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10 are set out in the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Act 1990 (the Act).

The penalty for non-payment of levies and charges, a breach of Regulation 3, is set out in section 8 of the Act. The penalty is a compounding rate of 2% per month of the total of outstanding levy and charge payments and any penalty that has accrued previously. Penalty ceases to accrue when only penalty remains outstanding.

The penalty for breaches of Regulations 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9 are set out in section 17 of the Act. The penalty for failing, without reasonable excuse, to provide a return or information is $6,000. The penalty for providing a false or misleading return or information is imprisonment for 12 months.

Regulation 10 details the information that must be given to a processor if a person wishes to claim an exemption from levy under paragraph 5 (2) (d) of the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1990. If a statement is not provided, the person is charged a levy. Although section 17 of the Act also applies to this Regulation, it would in practice only be applied in the case of a person providing a false or misleading statement.
The majority of the penalties were set out in the Act because there is a limit to the amount of penalty that may be imposed by Regulations, and heavier penalties must be imposed by the enabling Act.

I appreciate your concerns that the apparent absence of penalties could be seen as misleading. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that it is reluctant to adopt the practice of putting a note in Regulations drawing attention to the relevant provisions of an Act except in a special case as it is always necessary to read Regulations in the context of the enabling Act. In this instance, however, the Department does see the insertion of a note as a possibility.

I do not believe it would be worthwhile amending these particular Regulations given that they will soon be superseded by Regulations under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991. This Act incorporates the provisions of the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Act 1990 and several other levy and charge collection Acts falling within the administration of my portfolio. The new Act and its associated Regulations are expected to take effect from 1 July 1991. Your concerns will be taken into consideration when these Regulations are being drafted.
Yours fraternally
John Kerin

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to continuing reports concerning the poor state of bilateral relations with Malaysia. I further refer to the Minister's answer to a question in November relating to the cancellation of high level talks with Malaysia, in which he dismissed any suggestion that relations with Malaysia gave cause for concern with, `I do not deign to comment'. Will the Minister now deign to comment? Will the Minister explain to the Senate why the Government took so long to acknowledge the seriousness of the problem and to take steps to restore relations with an important regional neighbour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I did not deign to comment about in November was a remarkably fatuous addition to the substance of the question that was originally asked of me by Senator Hill-not unusual from him. I did make it clear in the substance of my answer, however-and I refer to it-on 8 November, that there was some negative reaction at senior government level in Malaysia to what had been perceived as offensive elements in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation series. I did acknowledge further down in that answer that there were misunderstandings which obviously existed between the two countries. I expressed the hope that those misunderstandings would shortly be resolved.

ANSWER.PARA: On other occasions I have made it perfectly clear in public comment that there is something of a problem in terms of our relationship. It is not a problem that I would wish then or now to exaggerate. It is a problem that we are living with and seeking quietly and patiently to work our way through. There are a number of conflicting and competing signals, which make it a difficult situation to read. There have been a number of negative comments, publicly made, and a number of actions taken, which have not been helpful in terms of maintaining the full flourish of our traditionally very warm bilateral relationship.

On the other hand, there have been a number of contrary indications that this is a problem whose magnitude, I say again, should not be exaggerated. Senator Robert Ray is shortly to visit Malaysia for a full bilateral visit. Prime Minister Mahathir has indicated as recently as yesterday that he is very willing to sit down and talk about the issues with Prime Minister Hawke in the middle of this year. Yesterday the High Commissioner, Frank Murray, was invited to and did attend an open house reception at the Prime Minister's residence. There has as yet been no indication that such difficulties as there are have, in fact, produced any serious problems in terms of our commercial, trade and investment relationship.

There are obviously issues which do require discussion between the two countries and we will address that. But the problem is not helped by jumping up and down and trying to make more of it than is in fact the case. I would hope that Senator Hill could on this, as on other matters, pay a little less attention to what he regards as his partisan obligations and a little more attention to his obligations as a Senate leader and spokesperson to act in a way that is beneficial to the interests of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What action has the Australian Government taken in response to the continuing violence and human rights breaches in Sri Lanka?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated on a number of occasions, the Australian Government continues to be deeply disturbed by events in Sri Lanka and by the consequent tragic loss of life, particularly in the north of the country. Over the past month there have been major clashes between Government security forces and Tamil Tigers in the Northern Mannar district. The aerial bombardment by the Sri Lankan Air Force in the area has eased. However, we do continue to receive reports of massacres of civilians by Government security forces and of Singhalese and Moslems by the Tamil Tigers, particularly in the east. For example, it was reported on 28 March that five Singhalese were killed by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) to the west of Amparai. On 31 March, 12 Tamil civilians were killed by the Batticaloa police. On 3 April the LTTE killed at least 11 and perhaps as many as 40 Singhalese and Moslem fishermen fishing in the Trincomalee Bay.

ANSWER.PARA: Through bilateral contacts, as well as in multilateral forums, the Australian Government has urged both the Sri Lankan Government and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam to end the fighting and to return to the negotiating table. We have repeatedly emphasised to the Sri Lankan Government the need to curb abuses committed by its security forces, although we do realise that the abuses which are occurring are not the sole responsibility of any one party to the conflict.

The Australian statement to the forty-seventh session of the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva in February this year underlined our ongoing concerns. We have also responded in other ways by contributing, for example, a total of $450,000 in emergency assistance to help alleviate the suffering of Sri Lankan civilians caught up in the hostilities. This assistance has been channelled through Australian and international organisations such as Australian Catholic Relief, Save the Children Fund and Community Aid Abroad.

This chamber has considered the Sri Lankan issue on a number of occasions, most recently on 7 March when we made clear our continuing support for an initiative involving the Commonwealth and hoped that President Premadasa and his Government would find it possible to respond positively to it. We will continue to make those representations to the Sri Lankan Government.

I want to conclude by saying that while there is a role for governments such as Australia in seeking to encourage a peaceful solution to the tragic situation in Sri Lanka, there is also a very real and constructive role to be played by members of the Tamil and Singhalese communities in Australia and elsewhere. At a meeting I had with representatives of the Tamil community in December, I expressed the hope that bridges could be built between the two communities as they can have an influence on developments in Sri Lanka by jointly calling for an end to violence and by encouraging a negotiated solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to his extensive press briefing yesterday about major changes to force structure and civilianisation of service jobs which he will announce in the Senate on 6 June. In view of the Minister's statements to the Senate Estimates Committee on the Defence estimates less than 24 hours prior to this briefing that he would not permit public discussion on these proposals before the statement, would he now revise this attitude? In light of speculation that one of the proposals he is considering is to cut the Regular Army's combat strength from six to four battalions, will the Minister give a commitment not to cut the existing capability of our combat forces?

—I think that Senator Durack is under a misapprehension as to what yesterday's defence correspondents lunch was about. It was not a briefing about the details of the force structure review and no such details were given. What it did do--
—They were printed.

—Let me assure Senator Durack that there were a couple of areas of speculation as to cuts, and I gave an explanation to the people at the lunch. Some people may well have some embarrassment later when the report is put down in Parliament because many of the press reports over the last few weeks have not been accurate; they have been speculative. Yesterday the general principles were stated. That is nothing new. They were laid down when we referred to an interdepartmental committee the report entitled Defence and the Community, known as the Wrigley report, and when I announced the force structure review. My statement yesterday was merely a reiteration of the philosophy behind that, that is, to do everything possible to increase the combat readiness and combat capability of the Australian defence forces. Details were not given of closure of bases or much else in the report. Just the philosophical issues were discussed.
—A training levy for reservists in the service?
—That was asked in the Estimates Committee, if Senator Newman must know. I understand that she was there at the time it was asked.
—I asked it.
—That is right. It was asked again yesterday and it got exactly the same response as Senator Newman got.
—That is something that is more than just a principle.
—I was there and Senator Newman was not. I guess that I will leave it to my better judgment as to who was right and wrong on these issues.
—Order! It is Senator Durack's question.

—There is often a little competition opposite as to who is shadow Minister. We have one, and we have an aspiring one. To reiterate and to contradict the assertion in Senator Durack's question, which I think implies that the people at the lunch yesterday were given a better briefing than the Estimates Committee-that is not the case. Details of the full structure review in the Wrigley report were not discussed but the general philosophy behind it was. There is nothing new in that.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: given that the Opposition has yet to provide details of its proposed consumption tax, can the Minister tell the Senate the likely impact of a broad-based consumption tax on low income earners and upon social welfare recipients? Is it true that such a tax would disadvantage those people who, of necessity, spend a greater proportion of their income on consumer goods? What are the consequences and what is the Government's attitude?

—There are some difficulties in attempting to discover exactly what kind of consumption tax might be proposed. In particular, it would be difficult to try to determine what the Opposition would propose if it were put in a position to implement one, given that we cannot find out much about its health policy-it has not managed that in four years-and given that it has not announced its social welfare policy because it cannot agree on one. As far as a consumption tax is concerned, the details remain very much shrouded in mystery. That would not bother some. It certainly would not bother Mr Reith. I will acknowledge that--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer you to your own ruling on 19 February 1987 when, in response to a point of order from the then Leader of the Opposition here, Senator Chaney, where he directed your attention to the fact that it was a question asked about Opposition policy, you ruled that the Minister was not permitted to proceed on that basis and he was only permitted to answer the question on Government policy. I ask you to uphold your own ruling.
—Order! Senator Richardson, do you wish to speak to the point of order?

—On the point of order: I do not recall Senator Loosely asking a question about Opposition policy. I heard him asking one about the likely impact of a broad-based consumption tax. In answering that question I believe I am entitled to comment on a broad- based consumption tax. The fact that there is a party in the Parliament which is proposing it is something that would have to be covered in giving an answer.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on that point of order. I quote what you said. On 19 February, you said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . that the majority of the question did refer to Opposition policies. I will allow it on the basis that the Minister answers only that part of the question that dealt with-
her portfolio and the Government's policy.
I ask you to uphold that ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second part of the question was certainly in order and I ask Senator Richardson to answer that question.

—The first problem with any broad-based consumption tax would obviously be that it would aggravate inflation. No-one can dispute that that is the case. For any consumption tax to have the kind of impact on Australia that anyone in the Opposition would like, let alone anyone here, we have to talk of at least a 15 per cent consumption tax. The reality is that that has a consumer price index (CPI) impact of 7 per cent.
—Do you represent Mr Keating here?

—No; I try to represent those who would be disadvantaged by a proposal that the Opposition is pushing. Naturally enough, those who would be disadvantaged most by a 7 per cent increase in the CPI are the poor and the disadvantaged. If they have any say in it, this tax will never see the light of day. When there is a 7 per cent impact on the CPI, one wonders what kind of effect that will have on food, clothing, medicines, medical service, books and a whole range of basic commodities that these people spend a much greater proportion of their incomes on than anyone in this room.
—Pornographic magazines.

—We will certainly be talking about magazines today. The Opposition has obviously entered that debate with some gusto over time and has sought to provide some enlightenment; it is just that it has failed miserably. Obviously, if a consumption tax were to be introduced by anyone, then providing compensation to the poor would be at the heart and the crux of the matter. As anyone who has ever toyed with the idea of a consumption tax would know, it becomes an incredibly complex and difficult area when one looks at compensation of the poor.
—Is that why you introduced one on orange juice?

—Senator Baume is hopeless. The problem is that, in the end, one can only have this compensation funded from somewhere. Unfortunately, the most recent suggestions for that funding state that it is to come from cuts in government spending. The billions of dollars that are required for cuts in government spending will only come from one area. If anyone in this chamber, no matter what side he or she was on, had to comment on what area those cuts would come from, that person need only look at Mr Reith's words when he said that unemployment benefits would be cut off for people who had been on the dole for nine months, and when his leader, Dr Hewson, said that people could live by their own means. It is a double whammy: not only do the poor have to suffer the inflation consequences of a 7 per cent increase--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. With respect, the Minister is now speaking against your ruling. His answer clearly has nothing to do with his portfolio. He is again speaking on Opposition policy, which you have already ruled out of order. I ask you to sit him down.
—Order! The Minister is entitled to answer a question on what the effects of a consumption tax would be. It is not the same as talking about an Opposition policy.
—If I had on a shirt like that, I would sit down.
—The shirt is a couple of years old. There is nothing new about it at all.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—The shirt certainly is not the subject of the answer. I was making the point that, in the end, the only way that compensation can be funded is by cuts in welfare payments to those who would be most disadvantaged by the tax in the first place.

—Mr President, I raise a different point of order. The Minister is now clearly debating the question. Furthermore, I can only conclude that if the matter is relevant to his portfolio it must be under active consideration to be introduced by the Government.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister's answer is a long one and it is not being helped by constant interjections. However, I ask the Minister to take that into account.

—As I said, there is just a double whammy for the poor in any suggestion of a broad-based consumption tax. Unfortunately, if it were to be introduced, only one party is pushing it. Given that party's dismal record of concern, one could imagine how the poor would be affected by it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I preface my question by noting that the 1990-91 Budget Papers, which give April 1990 prices, put the current project approval for the design and construction of six Collins class submarines at $4.187 billion. I further note that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, told the House of Representatives on 11 March that the project cost is $4.620 billion, also at April 1990 prices. The question of whether or not the person accused by the complainant should be arrested is, of course, entirely a matter for the Tasmanian police authorities to consider. Although I have not had a chance this morning, because of Estimates committees, to check, I understand that no arrest has been undertaken or effected at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the captain of the USS Missouri is cooperating with the State authorities in relation to the investigation of the alleged offence. If anyone is arrested in respect of the alleged offence, the manner of dealing with the matter is provided for in the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act and the Status of Forces Agreement between Australia and the United States (US).

In a case such as this, Australia has primary jurisdiction which would be exercised unless a formal request was received from the United States authority for Australia to cede jurisdiction to the United States and that request was granted by the Attorney-General. Such an application cannot be made until a person is arrested and charged. Until that first step is taken by the Tasmanian police authorities, none of the consequential seeking of displacing Australia's primary jurisdiction gets under way. In any case, in the end, the decision would be made by the Attorney-General as to whether to accede to the request if it were made by the US authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response. In the event of the jurisdiction being taken by American authorities, would all costs for the victim and her family, including loss of income, displacement, et cetera, be fully covered under the terms of this agreement?

—I am not sure of the arrangements in that regard. I do know that this is a mutual agreement and I do recall a case where an Australian sailor was accused of rape-I think in a United States port. The US authorities ceded jurisdiction to Australia and the sailor was dealt with by Australian court martial processes. As to the further question that has been raised by Senator Reynolds, I will seek to provide an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to his letter threatening the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters (FARB) because of advertisements radio stations are running opposing the Government's proposal to totally ban radio advertising on political matters. Is it a fact that paid advertisements condemning the Government for its proposed ban on political advertising on radio and television would be illegal under the Minister's proposed legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer raises the matter of correspondence between myself and Mr Martin Hartcher, the Federal Director of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, and makes the assertion that I threatened the Federation. At the end of the answer to this question, I will table the correspondence from myself to Mr Hartcher. In my correspondence to Mr Hartcher, I made a number of points. I drew his attention to the FARB fairness code for broadcasters and specifically to article 1 of the code, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: That to the best of our ability we will ensure the presentation of news and information with due accuracy and impartiality.
FARB claim that the code is a self-regulating code, and that it is best observed. I quote article 5 of the code:
. . . the successful operation of this Code depends on the spirit in which it is observed, and the exercise of reasonable judgment and good faith by broadcasters themselves.

I drew Mr Hartcher's attention to the fact that, in a number of advertisements organised and authorised by FARB, assertions were made which are totally inaccurate and that, as a consequence, that inaccuracy has led to a breach of that self-regulatory code that FARB has imposed on broadcasters. For instance, in one advertisement there is an assertion that:
This could be the last time you hear a radio announcement criticising an elected Government.

That is patently untrue. It may be something that the Opposition is trying to assert in the debate, but we have made it very clear that what we are tackling by our attempt to contain the costs of political advertising is advertisements. We are not in any way stifling or impinging upon news, current affairs or any other commentary or documentary on radio or television. That assertion in the advertisement is untrue and that has been brought to the attention of FARB. FARB goes on in its advertisement to say:
This could be the last time an individual has the right to speak their mind on the public airwaves.
That is also totally false, patently untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a stupid ad.
—As Senator Collins says, it is a stupid ad-very much so. The advertisement makes four assertions, and those four assertions are totally wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked, `Where does it get it wrong?'. I will go to another assertion. The advertisement states:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . you will never again hear any charity stating their case and asking for your support.

Once again, that is patently wrong. Once again, it is an assertion; it is part of the big lie that has been asserted by the Opposition. It is an assertion that has been picked up by FARB. But it is an assertion which is not consistent with the truth. On 20 March, when the Government announced this decision, we made it very clear that charities stating their case and asking for support would not be impinged upon by the ban.

The advertisement is littered with inaccuracies. It goes on to say that the Government will be free to advertise to `push their own . . . policies'. Once again, on that basic point, since 20 March we have made it clear that the Government will be controlled in the same way as the rest of the community. The advertisement is littered with falsities. It is irresponsible in the way it has been presented and it is an abuse of the code of FARB.

Apparently, FARB is going to write back to me to tell me that my correspondence to it will be circulated to its member broadcasters. If that is the case, if that is the response that comes through, it is just not good enough. We have here an industry which asserts to the public that it has a fairness code which it observes. We do not intend to, and would not, come in from the outside. But we say to this industry that if it presents to the Australian public a fairness in broadcasting code; if it presents itself as an industry which can regulate itself responsibly and be fair broadcasters in-quoting article 5 of its code-`the spirit in which it is observed' in a self-regulatory way; if FARB claims for itself the right, the responsibility and the authority to implement this code, it is therefore up to the FARB executive to ask that this advertisement, which it has produced itself and authorised, be rectified to the extent of its inaccuracies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Following the Minister's answer, I ask: under the proposed legislation, would the advertisements currently running on radio be illegal? Would John Laws and his radio station be subject to a fine under the proposed legislation and if this fine were not paid, would John Laws face possible imprisonment? Is it correct that Peter Westaway, former General Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party, party campaign director for New South Wales and Federal Treasurer of the ALP, is Acting Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT)? —I point out that another question was involved in that supplementary question. It is up to the Minister to answer as he thinks fit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, over the decade I have been here the Senate has been abused consistently in terms of personal slur and condemnation of individuals outside this place. I think, in respect of Mr Westaway, Senator Parer has not fallen into the gutter-he has gone right down below it. If people look at Mr Westaway's performance, they will assess that Senator Parer's question this morning is very much an unwarranted, outrageous and unfair attack on a senior and highly respected public servant who has served successive governments for 18 years. He has served not only Labor governments but also Liberal-National coalition governments. He has served Ministers such as Staley, Sinclair and Neil Brown. I would contend, not only to this Senate but also the Australian public, that those Ministers found him to be an extremely effective, loyal and competent policy adviser. Any innuendo that is made or asserted by Senator Parer is one that he should be embarrassed about and shameful of.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Westaway has served governments for 18 years. Any attack on his impartiality puts Senator Parer in the same gutter as Senator Bishop-both of them together. I mention Senator Bishop because she initially put out the press statement in which that assertion was made. That press statement goes very close to the parameters of the libel laws. I think both of them have a responsibility to give Mr Westaway an apology.

In respect of Mr Laws, let me say that the advertisements involved are on a political matter and they would come within the ambit of the legislation. Let me also say this, in conclusion: these advertisements are false, they are inaccurate and the people who authorised and produced them should know that. They have a responsibility to rectify them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would ask that you request the Minister to table the document from which he read relating to Mr Westaway.
—I will not table that document.
—Order! Senator Bolkus was going to table one letter.
—I will table my correspondence to the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister seen comments by the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, in the New South Wales Parliament yesterday that indicated that the Premier is backing away from his commitment to full disclosure legislation being introduced in New South Wales before the next election? Can the Minister comment on that backdown by Mr Greiner? I also ask the Minister: does the Government support a national approach to disclosure legislation so that people cannot use backdoor methods in order to evade honesty in politics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich raises a very serious issue-one which is of concern to the whole electorate; one which has gained universal response to the sort of reaction that the whole electorate wants from government-and the Opposition laughs at it. It just shows how irrelevant members of the Opposition are, how irrelevant they have been seen to be over the last decade to the electoral process and how irrelevant they will be seen to be when we go to the next election. I have seen the comments made by Premier Greiner, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today. While I can say that I am--
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I seek your guidance: is there a standing order that covers the eligibility of questions which are simply full of hypocrisy?
—Order! When the question was first asked of Senator Bolkus, I thought that the first part of it might be out of order; after hearing the full question, I believe that it is clearly in order.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. From the comments which I heard from Senator Bishop, I understand that she implied that there was hypocrisy in this question. I ask that Senator to withdraw those comments.
—Order!

—As I was saying, while I am disappointed at the Premier's change of heart as to the need for the full disclosure legislation, it really does not come as any surprise. When looking at the immediate history of this particular issue, we see that in May last year Commissioner Roden's report from the Independent Commission Against Corruption on north coast development in New South Wales was quite clear in the recommendations it made to the Government and to the parliamentary process in New South Wales. The report identified glaring loopholes in current laws for disclosure in New South Wales and it very clearly and directly called on all parties to support improved disclosure laws.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Greiner's response to that was quite equivocal. He set up a committee of the Parliament. I believed then, and we see now, that that committee was, obviously, just a pretence to buy time. Instead of acting immediately to draft legislation-which could now be law in New South Wales-Mr Greiner established a parliamentary committee. It is interesting to note that at the time, in May last year, Mr Greiner was quoted in a newspaper article as saying:
This is not an exercise to put it off until the 1996 election or anything like that . . .

Should an election be held now, the effect of the committee process is to ensure that the matter is put off until 1995. There is a bit of deja vu about all this, especially when one listens to Dr Hewson these days. In the same newspaper article Mr Greiner also said:
. . . our intention is to bring forward effective legislation on these matters prior to the next election.
It is definitely not the intention of the Government to put off the issue beyond the next election.

Mr Greiner's response is in stark contrast to that of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Carr, who then made a very clear commitment to support full disclosure, as recommended by Mr Roden at the time the report was released.

Mr Carr's commitment was quite different from that of the National Party of Australia. The National Party believed that disclosure was not in the best public interest. This was because the Roden report was scathingly critical of the activities of the National Party in New South Wales and its abuse of the disclosure laws in that State.

I go on to the second part of Senator Aulich's question in relation to Mr Greiner's comments regarding national legislation. I understand that Mr Greiner said that it made `significant sense' for there to be a national approach to this problem. The Government agrees that there needs to be a coordinated disclosure legislation approach throughout the Commonwealth. We will raise this with the States once our legislation goes through Parliament. At that stage, the coalition parties throughout the country will be put on the spot as to their commitment to the people of Australia. Those people will be able to test their bona fides in relation to their stated support for disclosure legislation.

As I said, in New South Wales Mr Carr has already made Labor's position clear. On 6 December 1990, he called for uniform Federal election funding laws. Given the National Party's response in New South Wales, we ask ourselves: what chance is there for a bipartisan response from that Parliament? It is not only New South Wales: even in Western Australia the Liberal Party has taken a similarly equivocal position to its Federal colleagues on disclosure. The National Party leader, Mr Cowan, is far less equivocal.

The time is coming for the Opposition. It has made statements in this Parliament in recent days saying that it supports disclosure-although quite limited and quite qualified and nowhere near the extent that is necessary to gain any confidence in its stated policy. I am sure that, as time evolves, those statements will be put to the test, not only in this Parliament but also in State parliaments. The Opposition's bona fides will be tested. I think we will find that its support for disclosure will develop into one that will be as reluctant as Mr Greiner's. It will try to find any way possible, any mechanism possible and any fallacious argument possible, as in the past, to oppose and try to defeat legislation which will make this parliamentary process transparent and open to the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I request that the Minister table the script from which he has just read.
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Last week, in answering a question, the Minister referred to `the corruptive influence' as one of the reasons for the need to amend the electoral Bill. I therefore ask the Minister: what evidence has he of any corruptive influence coming, or alleged to come, as a result of the use of radio or television in any Australian election?
—Are you a Tasmanian?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very quick and easy response to Senator Archer's question and it comes from Senator Sherry and Senator Cook. It basically refers Senator Archer to the current inquiry in Tasmania which goes very much to the heart of the relationship between corporate dollars and government. The Government has said from the start on this issue--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If they ask a question they should expect an answer. The Government has said from the start on this issue that the costs of campaigning in Australia have exploded over the last decade. Over the last three election periods the cost of electronic campaigning has increased threefold. In 1983--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My question was: what is the evidence of any `corruptive influence' coming, or alleged to come, as a result of the use of radio or television in any Australian election? I can say it more slowly if I have not got the question through.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. Basically, from the question and the point of order, it is quite clear to those people in this Parliament, and I am sure it will be quite clear to the people who may be listening to or watching this Question Time, that the Liberal Party does not acknowledge or understand the point of the concern out in the community. The concern out there is twofold: the cost of running campaigns in our society, and the need to ensure an open and transparent system so that the political parties and the process are open to public scrutiny.

ANSWER.PARA: I raise two very basic and simple principles, and all I get is abuse and interjections from the troglodytes on the other side. The basic point is that over the last three election campaigns the cost of electronic advertising has increased from $6 1/2m in 1984 to close to $19m, if not $20m, at the last election. In Australia we are spending something like $2.20 per elector on campaigning. In the United States (US) for a presidential election campaign the two major candidates are given $50m, which comes out to something like 20c per elector. That is not the total cost of campaigning in the US, but per head we probably exceed the US in the amount of money that we in this country spend on campaigning.

There is an acknowledgment by this side of the Parliament and people out in the community that the cost of campaigning must be contained. The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters targeted, as legitimate areas to address, not only electronic broadcasting or electronic advertising, but also the cost of campaigning. I will close on this point: advertising is not freedom of speech; advertising is bought speech and it is very expensively bought speech. It costs $13,000 per minute to exercise. It is available only to people in the electorate on the basis of the level of their bank accounts. It is an inherently undemocratic medium.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I would love to actually finish this answer. It is an inherently undemocratic process and medium, one that is accessible to people only in accordance with the level of their resources. We are concerned that in our process the principle of one person one vote, one vote one value is maintained. People will be able to use the mediums of radio and television to express their views, but they will not have to have a big bank balance to exercise them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that he raised this corruptive influence issue as an excuse for an amendment, even though there is not one single shred of evidence to justify such an allegation?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. It deals with the regional radio plan. Since 1987 only eight out of a designated 51 country FM radio stations have gone to air. Does the Minister admit that his regional radio plan has failed, and can the Minister tell us by what new process and when country listeners can expect to have access to high quality FM radio stations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of Senator Kernot having taken up this question in the Senate previously, I spoke to the Minister for Transport and Communications about it and he has provided me with the following response. The original radio program has achieved some success, but has also met serious delays. Ten new commercial radio services are now on air, following the announcement of the program. Three more licences have been granted and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has five inquiries into further licences under way.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear that the current program has not been effective in achieving the Government's objectives to introduce FM radio services into regional areas quickly and, where possible, as competing services. The reasons include changes in the economy and the broadcasting industry and also some deficiencies in the strategy. In addition, the present scheme unduly limits the access of existing broadcasters to the FM spectrum by placing too great an emphasis on supplementary licences and severely restricting the circumstances in which the conversion will be approved. The Minister would prefer to see such choices determined on a more commercial basis and intends that conversion should be an option in both sole and multi-station markets.

In reviewing the program, the Minister has found no reason to suggest that the Government abandoned the objectives of the program. However, he acknowledges that conditions in regional radio markets may not be as favourable to the introduction of new competitive services as was previously the case now that commercial radio revenue is declining.

The Department of Transport and Communications is developing an approach which will give maximum opportunity for all means of introducing FM services, and interested parties are now being consulted. A number of industry groups, representing both established radio operators and aspiring licensees, have already responded. The Minister intends to seek any necessary Cabinet agreement after these consultations are completed with the aim of seeing a substantial number of regional FM services initiated in the second half of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services and refers to his comments today on eliminating loopholes from disclosure. Given that the Cooke inquiry has already found that the existing audit provisions of section 275 of the Industrial Relations Act are insufficient because unions are not required to have a registered company auditor and given that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, an Australian Labor Party donor, has failed to lodge accounts in a timely fashion as is required under the law, how can we have `transparency and equity'-the Minister's own words-in disclosure until union accounts are required by law to be kept in a true and fair state, just like company accounts? Are the Minister's posturings about disclosure not a blatant case of one law for some and another law for the rest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never thought I would see the day-although I have always hoped for it-when one of the Nationals from Queensland would ask me about disclosure in public funding. I had hoped the Nationals would do it on the basis of two motivations: that they could offer to give expert evidence in helping us draft the legislation, or that they would dob in some of their mates. When we look at the litany of evidence in Queensland from the Fitzgerald inquiry we are talking about expert evidence.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator O'Chee is a bit raw in this place and I can understand that he may not have gone through the same sorts of processes. But one does not really expect National Party senators from Queensland to come in here as born again democrats, born again virgins, claiming honesty in this area and taking the high moral ground. It really does not fit the reality.

Senator O'Chee raises the question of audit provisions. Senator O'Chee should know that we have audit provisions in the Federal electoral Act, which have been there since about 1983-84. They provide for spot audits. In 1984, after the Federal election, the Australian Electoral Commission decided that it would conduct spot audits into the major parties. The Australian Labor Party indicated that it was prepared to have an audit of its accounts. Contrary to the spirit of an agreement that had been reached before the election, the Liberal Party of Australia responded with legal advice saying, `You cannot do it; you have to have reasonable suspicion of certain events having taken place to trigger off the audit'. The Liberal Party produced this advice and as a consequence of that instance in 1984-Liberal Party frustration of the auditing process-the audit provisions in the legislation have essentially been inoperable since then. Those provisions were rendered inoperable by a deliberate act of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: the question relates to the auditing of donors to political parties and in particular to the auditing of unions. I would ask you, Mr President, to direct the Minister to answer the question.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, the main bulk of the question was about union donations.

—Thank you, Mr President. I have made the point that those provisions have been rendered inoperative; they are general audit provisions. The other aspect of Senator O'Chee's question today is that it probably should have been ruled out of order because it does not belong to me. Industrial relations and unions are very much the province of my colleague Senator Cook and he may be able to give further information to the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How can we have equity and transparency in disclosure in the Bill, which the Minister is himself supposedly going to be preparing, if he cannot eliminate all the loopholes in disclosure that the Labor Party donors and unions currently enjoy and that everybody else does not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will add to my answer, given the fact that Senator O'Chee is making this point. I refer Senator O'Chee to sections 269(1) to (7) of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, which contain the provisions governing the grant of loans and donations by organisations to other organisations. There is in this legislation a framework of regulation.

ANSWER.PARA: I also refer Senator O'Chee and the Senate, and those here who refer to level playing fields with some cynicism, to the fact that already under industrial legislation union organisations and employer associations disclose annually income in expenditure statements. They are registered; they are available for the public to see. That law is there and it is being enforced.

I am further informed, and I believe, that in Queensland the Industrial Relations Act does require a registered auditor to audit union books. Those frameworks are already in legislation. It comes back to enforcement thereof. In that instance, one has to enforce the provisions. In our instance, we are talking about the first step, and that is a step of getting the legislation in place so it can then be enforced. We will ensure under that legislation that there will not be any more Fitzgerald inquiries, any more independent commissions against corruption and any more inquiries that are operating within the State sphere in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Industrial Relations that the affirmative action awards, which are provided by Portfolio magazine, were presented to winners in Sydney on Tuesday. Can the Minister inform honourable senators who the winners were this year and what their strategies are?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The women's magazine Portfolio announces annual awards for companies covered by the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 and, as Senator Giles rightly said in her question, it announced a number of awards on Tuesday of this week. The awards are designed to recognise outstanding affirmative action initiatives by organisations covered by the Affirmative Action Act. The companies that the magazine Portfolio chooses represent Australia's best equal employment opportunity practice.

ANSWER.PARA: The winners of the awards this year were: Nissan Motor Manufacturing Co. (Australia) Ltd in the category consultation; IBM Australia Ltd in the category achievement; L.M. Ericsson Pty Ltd in the category strategy; and the Murdoch University of Western Australia in the category higher education. I congratulate all those winners and in particular the overall winner, Nissan Australia.

Nissan Australia was awarded the overall prize for its outstanding equal opportunity program and, specifically, for its strategy to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace, its consultation on child-care and its video on equal opportunity and award restructuring. Nissan produced a video on equal opportunity, award restructuring and a team concept which was made available to its work force in both English and, because of the high migrant content of its work force, Vietnamese as well. Information workshops were held and all training for supervisors included information on sexual harassment. Contact officers were nominated throughout the organisation.

A major child-care feasibility study was undertaken by Nissan, which involved extensive consultations with employees, unions and management. Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I should draw attention to the astonishing level of interjection in this chamber. It seems that when I enunciate the positive features of a model employer in this country, the Opposition does not want to know about it.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I would ask you to draw the Minister to order. He is claiming that the Opposition does not want to know about this. The Opposition already knows about it. If the Minister does not know about it, he is a couple of days late.
—There is no point of order.

—I should mention the other enterprises: Murdoch University is to be congratulated for its efforts in enticing women to return to postgraduate study; IBM for its success in retraining and promoting women; and L.M. Ericsson for its affirmative action strategies which target both current and prospective employees. I commend all those companies as good examples of human resource management.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that this is a positive private sector response to a Government Act on equal opportunity which is now being taken up by a popularly circulating women's magazine and is a good example of the Government, the private sector and the publishing industry working together to promote ideal employment practices in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask: of the 5,000 female lawyers in Australia, what special and particular qualities does Miss Kavanagh bring to the Australian Sports Drug Agency which sets her apart from the other 4,999?

—I was not aware that the selection of one person is any reflection on the rest. I am sure that there are 5,000 women lawyers in Australia who would do an adequate job. But one cannot take on 5,000, so one excellent person has been appointed.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: has the Minister seen a report in yesterday's Melbourne Age that claims departmental documents contradict his statement to the Senate on 18 February regarding advertising in an Australian Council of Trade Unions-sponsored Cleo supplement in March? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

SUBJECT: Supplementary Question from Senator Coulter
HANSARD 17 APRIL 1991-Arsenic in Seaweed
The Minister for Community Services and Health has supplied the following reply to the Hon. Senator's supplementary question.

``I understand that the Food Science and Technology Subcommittee (FST) at its 81st meeting in February 1991 considered the question of the public health implications of arsenic in imported seaweed and determined that on the limited toxicological data available to it, it was not possible to recommend a change to the food and arsenic level combinations specified by the Food Standards Code (FSC). The subcommittee did not consider the significance of cadmium in seaweed.

At its March 1991 meeting, the Public Health Committee reviewed an independent toxicological report assessing the public health implications of both inorganic and organic arsenic and cadmium in seaweed. The report assessed all available scientific data on inorganic and organic arsenic in seaweed, including recent data not available to FST, as well as the implications for health of the levels of cadmium detected. The report concluded that:

consumption of inorganic arsenic at the levels found in six out of seven seaweed samples assessed by Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS), would be well below the internationally accepted intake level set by the Joint Who Health Organisation/Food and Agricultural Organisation Expert Committee on Food Additives;
the majority of organic arsenic in seaweed is in the form of arsenosugars (ribofuranosides) which are rapidly excreted in the urine and therefore pose no toxicological hazard to human health;
overall, there was no evidence to suggest that the current levels of organic arsenic compounds found in seaweed constitute a risk to human health;
The permissible levels of cadmium in seaweeds need to be set in line with other potential dietary sources of cadmium.
The report indicated the need for:
further research on the nature and properties of organic arsenic in seaweed;
AQIS to undertake a comprehensive monitoring program of cadmium, organic and inorganic arsenic levels in imported seaweed over the next two years;
AQIS to be asked to provide detailed data on the different types of seaweeds entering Australia.

I am advised that the Public Health Committee supported the thrust of these conclusions and agreed to recommend an interim standard pending the provision of more comprehensive data. The Australian Quarantine Inspection Service is being asked to establish a comprehensive monitoring program. The NHMRC will maintain a continuing review of the recommended standard.''

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 18 April, from Senator Hill:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, to protect Australia's interests by recalling the Ambassador to Ireland and The Holy See, Mr Brian Burke, in circumstances in which Mr Burke is not prepared to stand down whilst serious allegations against him are examined by the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, to protect Australia's interests by recalling the Ambassador to Ireland and The Holy See, Mr Brian Burke, in circumstances in which Mr Burke is not prepared to stand down whilst serious allegations against him are examined by the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.

Australia's standing cannot be put at risk by the need to protect mates. In the case of Ireland and the Holy See Australia's representation is in the hands of Mr Brian Burke. Senators might be interested to know what the terms of his appointment are. What are the letters of credence? While the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade apparently does not have a copy specifically in relation to Mr Burke, it is able to give the form. It is in the form of a letter from Mr Bill Hayden, the Governor-General of Australia, to the President of the Republic of Ireland and His Holiness the Pope, in the case of the Holy See. It says:
Your Excellency,
Being desirous to maintain and promote without interruption the relations of amity and concord which so happily exist between-
Ireland, the Holy See-
and Australia, I have appointed-
Mr Brian Burke--
to reside near You in the character of Ambassador-
Mr Burke's-
high character, ability and commitment to duty assure me that he will discharge the duties of his Mission in such a manner as to merit Your approval and esteem.

I therefore request that Your Excellency receive him favourably and give full credence to all that he may communicate to You in the name of Australia, and especially when he renews to You the assurance of my continuing interest in and good wishes for-

Ireland and the Holy See. Here is Mr Burke, in the name of Australia under the name of Bill Hayden, the Governor-General of Australia, put to Ireland and the Holy See as a man of high character, ability and commitment to duty with the responsibility of speaking for Australia.

As I said, Mr Burke is the highest representative of Australia in Ireland and the Holy See. If there is a question mark over Mr Burke, there is a question mark over Australia. No Australian government, meeting its national responsibility, can allow that to happen. No foreign Minister, in particular, meeting his responsibility of protecting Australia's standing internationally, can permit such a situation to continue. No ambassador with any real interest in Australia's international reputation could not stand down in the circumstances in which Mr Burke finds himself today.

The difference here is that Mr Burke operates at a different level from other ambassadors. He is a Labor hero; he is a Labor mate. Labor mates look after each other. In this instance, Mr Burke has mates at the highest level who put loyalty to their mate ahead of their duty. We understand that Mr Hawke, Mr Keating, Senator Richardson and Mr Beazley are Mr Burke's mates. They are his security blanket; they are his protectors.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who must know that his failure to act is in dereliction of his duty, regrettably has not the strength to stand up to the Beazleys, Hawkes, Keatings and Richardsons. I regret to say that that will forever be a mark against the record of Senator Evans who, we are prepared to acknowledge, has worked hard for Australia's interests in other ways. In this instance, Senator Evans has sold Australia short and, in doing so, he has sold himself short. We understand that Senator Evans owes the Party and apparently is prepared to accept the tarnishing of his reputation out of this failure to act, out of this abdication of responsibility.

If it had been any other diplomat, any professional diplomat, not one of Labor's political mates, he would have been pulled back a long time ago. Senator Evans, with anguish on his face, would have said in this place that it is something he regretted having to do but something that had to be done in Australia's interests.

Serious allegations have been made against Mr Burke-allegations of gross impropriety for the way he conducted the business of government when he was Premier of Western Australia. Mr Deputy President, you will know that now the allegations go even beyond the time when he was Premier of Western Australia; there is now evidence before the Royal Commission that Mr Burke involved himself in a Western Australia Inc. deal after he had quit politics and whilst he was ambassador-designate.

It is important to stress that we have not said that Mr Burke is guilty of any offence. We acknowledge that he has not been charged with any offence, let alone been found guilty of any offence. That is not the point. The point is: what is the proper conduct in these circumstances where he is faced with these allegations, particularly now when there is a royal commission investigating these allegations? The proper course of action is for Mr Burke to stand down while these allegations are being tested.

In some ways, that might seem harsh. It might seem harsh on the individual to have to stand down in such circumstances. But when in public office, it is part of the cost of that office, because protection of the office must come first. That is why the precedent is well established: Phillip Lynch in 1977; Mick Young in 1984; Neville Wran in 1986. To stand down is not to be judged guilty; it is to do the right thing to protect the office. In this case, because Mr Burke is an ambassador of Australia, to stand down is to protect the national interest. If Mr Burke cannot see that, the Minister should act.

Mr Burke has not acted and that is why we have said and say again today that the Minister should act. For months, Senator Evans, faced with this issue, has refused to act. We can go back to 6 November last year when we raised the issue of the relationship of Mr Burke to the convicted phone tapper, Smith. Mr Burke now admits that he was paying for a dirt search on a Liberal politician.
What was Senator Evans's response? He said on that day:
I have no knowledge of the article -
he referred to an article in the press-
or report to which he-
that was Senator Crichton-Browne-
refers. I will dig it up-
which seems to be an apt choice of words in the circumstances-
and see what action may be appropriate in all the circumstances.
A week later, on reflection, he said:
I do not think there is any foundation for any suggestion of improper behaviour on the part of the former Premier . . .

So he tells us that these circumstances, where Mr Burke has now subsequently acknowledged that on his last return to Australia he did engage this now convicted phone tapper Smith to gather material on Liberal politicians, are not a matter of concern.

We on this side of the chamber believe that that is a demonstration of an appalling standard. It demonstrates to us that Mr Burke, on those circumstances alone, is not a fit and proper person to have been appointed to the office that he now holds. That is not to suggest illegality. That is to say that, in our opinion, he clearly behaved in a grossly improper way, a way which is not in accordance with the standard of all decent Australians. But he was, as I said, absolved by Senator Evans. Of course, he was absolved because he is a Labor mate.

In the ensuing months, Senator Evans constantly changed his position. He ducked and weaved. Sometimes he said he would not look at the evidence; sometimes he said that he would not act on the evidence. When he was presented with examples, particularly by Senator Campbell, of conflicting evidence by Mr Burke to other inquiries and commissions in Western Australia, what did he say? Senator Evans said:
If and when some evidence emerges through the courts or a Royal Commission of something which would make it inappropriate for the ambassadorial position to be maintained I will act, but not sooner.
On 17 December he said, `That may well be in the context. Something might develop in the context of a commission. That could be the type of evidentiary status that I am talking about'.
Again, on 21 February, as we continued to pursue this question, urging Senator Evans to meet his responsibility, he said:

If and when some hard evidence emerges through the courts or a Royal Commission of something which would make it inappropriate for his ambassadorial posting to be maintained I will act, but not sooner.

`If some evidence emerges through the courts or a Royal Commission'. On other occasions, as I said, Senator Evans simply refused to look at the material. I remind the Senate of a long list of documents that were brought to his attention by Senator Campbell on 21 December. Senator Evans's answer as to whether he would examine that material to see whether the Ambassador was acting in a proper way was, simply, `No'.

Then when evidence started appearing through the Royal Commission, Senator Evans changed his position again. In that instance he said that he would await the outcome of the Commission. So we went through a sequence: first that he would look at the evidence that was put before a royal commission; when evidence started to appear, he said that he would await determination by the Royal Commission. In that instance, on 13 March, he said that he would `await the outcome of those Royal Commission proceedings'.
Of course, now he has gone one step further in that he made what could be described as the final reversal the other day when, on 10 April, he said:
If such an allegation were made otherwise than in the context of the currently proceeding Royal Commission, of course I would investigate it . . .

So now the allegations are being made in the Commission and evidence is being put before the Commission, Senator Evans is in trouble because of the previous undertakings he gave. So he takes a step in another direction and says, `If it had occurred other than in a royal commission, I would look at it'. But, yet, he refused to look at Senator Campbell's evidence that had been put before him.

We have this pattern of stone-walling, changing positions, a failure to look at the evidence and a failure to act. That, we argue, is failing to face up to the responsibility of being Minister. But in addition to that there is the embarrassment of Mr Burke degrading his office even further when he returned to Australia last month and embarked on a media circus-even doing a talk-back program under the title `Ask the Ambassador'. This was Mr Burke in full political swing. What did Senator Evans say in answer to another question on 5 March? He said:
There is something of a convention that ambassadors do not comment on political or related matters.

But did this test apply to Mr Burke? Of course not, because Mr Burke is a special case. It would apply to any other ambassador, but not to Mr Burke. He is a Labor hero; he channelled hundreds of thousands of dollars to Labor's Federal campaigns. He has to be protected.

Now, of course, Mr Burke is back in Australia again on special leave and special pay-a discretion exercised by Senator Evans; a special privilege arising out of a special relationship. It does not apply to other ambassadors. He did not tell the Minister that he was returning to Australia in this instance. He did not tell the Minister that he was returning to Australia in the previous instance. He has not told the Minister on how many other occasions he will have to return to Australia in order to deal with the 12-odd major matters that are still before the Commission which could take the next 12 months to two years to complete.

What happens to his responsibilities in Ireland? Of course, for Mr Burke they are put aside and, apparently, that is satisfactory to the Minister-special circumstances for a special ambassador. This is an ambassador who is not doing his job; he is now back in Australia answering allegations before a royal commission. Who is thinking of the interests of Australia in this matter? Certainly not Mr Burke and certainly not Senator Evans.

There is a clear case of failure by Senator Evans to act in the way that he should. The purpose of this motion, as Mr Burke returns to Australia, is for the Senate to communicate that view to Senator Evans. Senator Evans knows what he should do. He knows how he should be acting in this matter. He knows that he should not be protecting Labor's mates and putting them above the national interest. Senator Knowles will remind Senator Evans of the allegations and the evidence before Mr Burke. Senator Campbell in this debate will remind Senator Evans of the views of independent commentators and the overseas reaction to this appalling situation. Hopefully, Senator Evans will now finally exercise his responsibility-the responsibility that he should have exercised a long time ago. I commend the motion to the Senate.
