SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, I am of course extremely conscious of the need to protect Australia's interests abroad; I spend my working life doing just that with the help, I might say, of a very distinguished and competent Australian diplomatic service. But I am also conscious of the need to do a few other things. I am conscious of the need to respect the basic principles of justice and fairness to individuals-the Australian tradition of respect for which is of course an important part of the respect with which we, in turn, as a country continue to be held overseas. I am conscious also of the need to act consistently and in accordance with clearly enunciated principles. I am conscious also of the need to resist what are, essentially, squalid partisan politically-inspired attacks dressed up in terms of high principle, but which, in reality, are nothing of the kind.

SPEECH.PARA: The starting point in my response to this whole matter must of course be the principle of presumption of innocence-that no-one should be judged guilty of criminality by a criminal court, or judged guilty of impropriety by a royal commission before that person is the subject of sworn evidence which is tested and replied to, and is the subject of a concluded decision by the appropriate properly-constituted tribunal.

Allegations are always cheap, and allegations made before royal commissions, with their wide-ranging investigatory briefs and their rather looser rules of evidence, are traditionally very cheap indeed. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I and other members of the Government have made clear on innumerable occasions that we do not regard mere allegations-albeit allegations in a royal commission in a sworn evidentiary context-wherever they come from, as being the basis for standing down anyone. That is not only a principled position, but also it is one that is manifestly in accordance with practical commonsense.

The alternative would be to accept the principle that anyone in public life in an important position of responsibility should be required to stand down, either voluntarily or involuntarily, when a serious allegation was made against him or her. But one has only to state that proposition for its manifest absurdity to become apparent. It would only be a matter of the Leader of the Opposition or someone giving evidence in some context or other making an allegation against the Prime Minister, for the Prime Minister to be required to stand down. It would only be a matter of such an allegation being made against a Minister-particularly, let us say, a Minister exercising important judicial-type responsibilities, like an Attorney-General-for that person to have to stand down. I recall that similar claims were made against me during my tenure of that particular job. It would only require similar sorts of allegations to be made against a member of a judicial tribunal or, indeed, a court for that particular public office-holder to be required to stand down.

Given the reality of the robust character of political debate in this country, with allegation and counter-allegation being very much a part of the stock-in-trade, and given the way in which royal commissions have become so much a part of the tapestry of everyday life in this country, with all of the allegations and counter-allegations that flow from them, we would face the prospect-if the principle that a mere allegation required an obligation to stand down were to be accepted at face value-of the ministerial benches and judicial benches of this country being progressively denuded. This whole question of course is one that the Prime Minister has put on a number of occasions squarely and directly to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Over and again the Leader of the Opposition has been asked and has steadfastly refused to answer whether it is his position that the mere making of an allegation requires the person in question to stand down or be stood down.

I now ask the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) the same question. Is that what he is saying-that the mere making of an allegation is something that should require a public officer-holder, in a responsible position, against which that allegation is made to stand down or be stood down? Does anyone in the Opposition hold that position in the full robust terms that were so clearly implied by the nature of what Senator Hill and Dr Hewson have been saying in recent days? If Opposition senators do hold that position, in all its rigour and in all its absoluteness, they are committed to a position of manifest absurdity. If they do not hold that position, then they are convicted of manifest hypocrisy and humbug. That is the nub of the response that we make to the Opposition on that point.

I acknowledge that the principle of presumption of innocence, as I have described it, while being the starting point of our consideration of, and reaction to, this matter and while it should remain the central guiding principle that continues throughout the duration of this matter, is not necessarily the finishing point. I acknowledge that there are some additional considerations that I, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, do have to take into account when a situation of the kind that presently confronts us arises.

Those considerations that I have to take into account go basically to the question of the effectiveness with which Australian interests are represented abroad. As I said in this place on 10 April, it is the case that a situation such as a royal commission inquiry can impose very considerable pressures of time and the like on a person caught up in it.

From the outset, as I also said on 10 April, Ambassador Burke has made very clear to me and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that he is very conscious of his responsibilities to continue to discharge his ambassadorial duties effectively, and he will keep that very much in mind in terms of judging his own position as the matter develops. On the same day the Prime Minister said in the other place:
. . . if a situation arose where the actual discharge of his duties was in question-his capacity to discharge his duties-I would expect that Mr Burke would make that judgment.
The Prime Minister went on to say:
All I can say is that on the evidence available to me at this point I have no evidence that the Ambassador is not able to discharge his duties.

I have made the same judgment up to this point of time. It will be a matter for continuing judgment, based on the circumstances, as to whether that conclusion should continue to be reached. I readily acknowledge that a judgment about this matter, while it is one for Mr Burke in the first instance, is ultimately one for me. I make the point, however, that, in all the circumstances as they are known to me in terms of Mr Burke's capacity to effectively discharge his duties and in terms of the pressures of time and like put upon him, at this point of time there is no basis on which any judgment should be made other than the one that has been made.

Of course, the point will be made-it has been implied already in what Senator Hill said-that it is not just a matter of physical pressures and effectiveness to do the job in that sense; it is also a matter, it is said, of Australia's reputation and standing when allegations of impropriety are being made about someone of the stature and position of an Australian ambassador abroad.

The first point I make about that is this: it should not be assumed that any adverse consequences of this kind do flow automatically so far as other governments are concerned. Other governments are perfectly capable of distinguishing wild and woolly allegations from concluded, royal commission findings. Other governments are perfectly capable of understanding the political context in which allegations made in a royal commission context can achieve a degree of prominence and notoriety. I believe that the Irish Government, with its own robust political tradition, which we perhaps inherited in this country, is more capable than most governments around the world of understanding the political realities of situations like this.

I go on to make a second point: these situations do nonetheless have to be carefully monitored, and there may conceivably be circumstances that arise where an issue becomes so prominent in the overseas media and so much a matter of comment or articulated concern by host governments that it is desirable for the position of an ambassador to be reconsidered. My Department and I, together with Ambassador Burke and his missions in Dublin and the Holy See, are obviously continuing to monitor the situation very carefully in this respect.

Again, all that I can say is that up to this point-and I say this on the basis of communications received as recently as this morning-I have made the judgment that, in terms of the attention this matter is generating in the countries in question and in terms of the reaction that it is generating in the host governments in question, there is no basis at the moment for this kind of reconsideration being given.

I do not want to say anything more than that. I believe that I have said enough to make it clear that, notwithstanding the temptation to respond in kind to the essentially partisan character of the Opposition's posturing on this urgency motion, I make the point that I and the Government understand perfectly well the principles that are applicable to this whole matter, and we are applying those principles in a measured and principled way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats recognise this debate today for what it is. It comes to the Senate as a matter of urgency because for the Opposition it is urgent. According to all reports, the Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See is returning as soon as he can get here to answer the allegations referred to in the motion. It is therefore an opportunistic political exercise by the Opposition that it has to undertake today because, with a two-week break coming up, such a move will be well and truly out of date when we come back.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not to say that the Democrats are not, like the community at large, appalled at what lies at the base of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in relation to WA Inc. and the allegations against Mr Burke and others-the smell of political corruption.

It is important to note that, with all the hoo-ha surrounding WA Inc., the role of the Ambassador and the pressure that the Opposition has chosen to put on the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans)-apart from the obvious embarrassment for both of the big parties, with colleagues of the mover of this motion, both in the other place and even in this place, having the heat put on them-the real import of what is coming out of WA Inc. is probably twofold: firstly, the huge amounts of money that must be raised by political parties to pay for election campaigns and, secondly, the inadequacy of the current law in that respect. The revelations concerning WA Inc. may be distasteful, even immoral, but they are not illegal, and they should be.

Today's debate, as I have said, is an exercise in political opportunism and of no substance with regard to the point that I have just made. Worse, it comes in a slightly unusual manner on a day when public servants have readied themselves for Estimate committee hearings which were scheduled to begin before this time. They will have to wait, they will be here later today than they otherwise would have been and they will not get on with their further work. Not only is this a waste of time but it also has the potential to waste public money.

Hence, the Democrats will, with the exception of this short explanation that I am giving now, participate no further in this debate. It is an exercise of political head kicking between the two big parties in which we do not want to participate; nor will we participate in the vote. We will, with extreme pleasure, participate in the substantive debate that will come before this place to address the underlying issues of the remaining legality of immoral practices in the political process which, fortunately, will now come before us as a result of the WA Inc. royal commission and the Government's initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) talked about justice, fairness, consistency and politically inspired attacks. It is a shame that he has viewed this debate in such a shallow manner. The Australian Democrats, of course, have simply talked about opportunistic political exercises and about Estimates, which I do not think have any relevance to this debate today at all. It just goes to show how little the Democrats really understand the problems at the core of this matter. Put simply, it is not in the interests of Australia for one of its diplomats to remain in his post when he faces prolonged appearances before a royal commission and when he has been the subject of repeated evidence as to a lack of propriety in his previous career.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has spoken today about allegations-mere allegations. I keep repeating: these are not just mere allegations; these are statements that are made on oath. In previous months the Minister saw a royal commission as being serious enough to give a commitment to act upon but now he views the evidence given on oath provided at that royal commission as insufficiently important. This is why the coalition asks the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to have regard for the standing of Australian diplomatic representation and to recall, or at least suspend, Mr Brian Burke as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See.

The Hawke Labor Government has consistently put the demands of the political mateship culture ahead of propriety in the handling of this matter, ever since serious evidence was raised in Federal Parliament nearly six months ago and concerns about Mr Burke's propriety to hold the job were raised as far back as March 1988. So this is not some new revelation purely and simply as a consequence of the Royal Commission. It goes back to March 1988.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and his colleagues have hidden behind the fiction that the coalition has accused Mr Burke of criminal activity, which he again accused us of today, so that the principle of innocent until proven guilty in a court of law can be invoked. I have not resiled one inch from my position and statement of 19 December 1990 that the issues we are raising here deal with propriety, not criminality. It is not a crime to seek political donations, to operate bank accounts, or to hire private detectives to investigate and spy on opponents. These activities can, however, be conducted in a fashion that debases politics in a manner that is self-evident.
It is deplorable that Senator Evans should abandon his duty to uphold the standing of our diplomatic representation by declaring in answers to questions that he will take no action unless:
. . . evidence emerges through the courts or elsewhere of something which would make it inappropriate for the Ambassadorial position to be maintained.

He stated that on 27 November. I am sorry, but Senator Evans cannot have it both ways: he cannot say that he is going to act in that manner then and do the reverse now. Prior to the Royal Commission he said he would wait for the Royal Commission. Now he says he will await evidence from elsewhere. Where else are we going to get evidence from? We will eventually get evidence in the courts. In taking this stand Senator Evans has chosen to ignore evidence that has emerged in the investigation of Government surveillance by a select committee of the Legislative Council of Western Australia and the royal commission. It is worth noting that Senator Evans is now leaving the chamber during this debate, that he does not consider this debate an important one which goes to the core of Australia's representation overseas.

It is admitted by Mr Burke's former personal assistant, Mr Shervington, that the Premier instructed convicted phone tapper Robert Smith to `get something' on Liberal members of State Parliament. It is admitted by Mr Burke's former media adviser that he acted as a go-between in arranging payment for private work done by Smith for the Premier. These are not wild allegations by Mr Burke's political enemies; they are statements made before a proper investigative body by people with no interest in maligning Mr Burke. Yet the Minister dismissed them as a political attack and chose to ignore the serious questions of propriety that are raised in this debate.

Mr Burke has also been linked with his brother to the bribery of Stirling City Council councillors to vote to allow a development to be built on the Scarborough beach front. Senator Beahan may also like to tell the Senate what he knows about this matter. Then, of course, there are the incredible and extensive allegations about Brian Burke's role in the warehousing of the Fremantle Gas and Coke Co. Additionally, there are very serious questions about his fundraising methods-funds for favours. Most recently, it has been alleged that Mr Burke while being ambassador-designate had approached a businessman to be guarantor for a WA Inc. deal concerning the carve-up of the Bell Group.

The appointment in Western Australia of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters has actually been used by this Minister and his Government as an excuse for inaction, until the outcome of the Commission. How very convenient! Prior to the Royal Commission it was used as the excuse for potential action. The Royal Commission may not deliver its findings until well into 1992, during which time Mr Burke is presumably welcome, according to this Government, to remain as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, as our representative.

During this month the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade have taken to covering themselves by reference to Mr Burke's own judgment as to whether he can fulfil the requirements of his office. The Prime Minister evades the question, claiming that the Opposition in effect demands that every public official subject to any allegation be stood aside. Yet I repeat: the matters that question Mr Burke's propriety are not allegations, but evidence presented to proper inquiries and under oath.

It is an insult to the Western Australian royal commissioners to imply that they allow wild allegations to be made before the Commission. Is this Government suggesting that the commissioners allow people to wander in day after day and lie? If it is not suggesting that, then Senator Evans should act, and act now.

The Government pretends that the normal rules have been applied in granting Mr Burke special leave rather than standing him aside. How can there be any such thing as normal rules in a situation that is unprecedented as far as diplomatic representation is concerned? It is fiction that Mr Burke is in the same position as a career diplomat forced to return to Australia because of some personal matter.

We may ask why it was necessary for Mr Young to stand aside as a Minister in 1983 during investigation of the Combe-Ivanov affair, yet Mr Burke is allowed to remain in his position. No doubt it is useless to cite the precedents where Ministers in the last coalition Government were required to stand down until their names were cleared because different rules apply.

The nonsense of the claim that Mr Burke is not receiving special treatment is refuted by the former head of the Foreign Affairs Department, Mr Alan Renouf, in stating that a career diplomat would not receive the same degree of latitude. He was interviewed on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Perth on 12 April last week. As a former career diplomat, he said that the same rules would not apply. It is a sad state of affairs for Mr Renouf to confirm that such a situation has not previously involved an Australian ambassador.

It is not in Australia's interest that a person remain representing us overseas when questions are to be answered about the purpose of massive cash donations passed to a private secretary to Mr Burke as Premier, when she is not quite sure what she did with one $100,000 cash sum. It is not in the national interest for Mr Burke to remain as a serving ambassador when questions need to be answered as to the leader's accounts that he kept under close personal control, and when there is a serious question of propriety as to the nature of the hard-sell fundraising adopted by him as Premier. It is not in the national interest when questions remain unanswered about a $55,000 cheque that came from the Perth mint in exchange for gold and went straight into the leader's account. It is not in the national interest for someone to remain as ambassador when it is reported that a respected Western Australian business identity, Ralph Sarich, has suffered in his dealings with State governments headed by Mr Burke and his successors because he refused to make political donations.

If the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives is prepared to state that, if a Premier is seen to be involved in authorising surveillance, he should stand down. It is, after all, Mr Ronald Edwards who cited the example of Watergate. Lawyers may argue whether Nixon broke the law, but few will dispute that he acted improperly and debased his office.

Serious evidence of impropriety is squarely before this Labor Government. The Minister should stop protecting his Leader's mates and uphold the national interest by requiring Mr Burke to follow relevant precedent and stand down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating a matter of urgency which was put to the Senate by Senator Hill. Essentially, the matter of urgency which Senator Hill wants the Senate to determine is whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, should recall the Ambassador to Ireland, Brian Burke, because of some allegations that have been made against Brian Burke in the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, which is currently being heard in Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened very carefully to what Senator Hill had to say in support of his motion. Obviously, I may not have the correct words that he used; I will use the words as I noted them-and if there are any corrections to be made later we can certainly do that. Senator Hill said, `We have not said that he'-that is, Brian Burke- `is guilty of anything'. Senator Hill put that statement on the record. He then went on to acknowledge that Brian Burke has not been charged with anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't deny any of that.
—You have rushed to judgment.

—Yet the Opposition is determined to rush to judgment, as my colleague Senator Cook said, and is determined to destroy the career path of this great Australian, great Western Australian. The Opposition is determined to do that. An accusation of Senator Hill is that Brian Burke may be guilty of being a Labor hero. That certainly was the case in February 1983 when Brian Burke, as the leader of the party in that State, took us into government after quite a period of time in the wilderness. Certainly, because of his actions as leader of the Western Australian Government on behalf of the people of Western Australia, he will remain a hero for many days to come.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been indicated that he is a Labor mate, whatever that term means. I would be more than happy to claim Brian Burke as a Labor mate, although in years gone by Brian Burke, because of his particular persuasions within the Labor Party, would certainly not have claimed me as a Labor mate. But, internal differences aside, Brian Burke has made an enormous contribution to the Labor Party, to Western Australia and, indeed, to Australia.

Brian Burke is accused of gross impropriety. We were told by Senator Hill that Senator Knowles would list exactly what Brian Burke is being accused of-not being charged with. Senator Knowles has repeated some of the assertions that have been made previously in this place, in the other place and, indeed, in the Royal Commission in Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Statements under oath.

—Statements under oath are all very fine. But there have been instances in Australia where individuals have gone into courts and royal commissions and have lied on their oath. People have gone to prison because they have lied on their oath.
—Are you suggesting that they are all lying?

—I am not saying they are lying. I am not making a judgment. I am putting to the honourable senator that it is very easy, as Senator Evans said, to make an accusation. Indeed, in this privileged place in the Parliament of Australia, since we are distant from the causes, we can make accusations with impunity because of parliamentary privilege.
—Have we done that?

—We should not abuse that privilege, and I am certainly not accusing Senator Campbell of abusing the privilege. But at the same time we do have to set some standards. I suggest that the Opposition should look to accepting and replying to the challenge put to them by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the other place on 16 April. The challenge is: how does one gauge the principles? I quote the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if an allegation is made against an official, then that allegation of itself is sufficient to require the Government to stand down the person against whom the allegation is made.
Is that going to be the standard? The Opposition, both in the other place and here-and the challenge has been put out again by Senator Evans-has not yet responded to it.

If the Opposition responds to that challenge in the affirmative, I suggest that all of us will be on very shaky ground indeed. We must face the fact that accusations and allegations can be and, indeed, are made on a continual basis-and not only against us as politicians. What happens if allegations are made against a member of the judiciary? If it is merely an accusation or allegation, would that member of the judiciary be immediately expected to stand aside? If the allegations continued once the pattern of events was accepted out there in the community, we would quite soon end up in a state of anarchy. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber must address the standards and principles that it is going to bring to bear to this debate surrounding the Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke.

Senator Hill mentioned people who had perhaps set standards by stepping aside from their office when allegations and assertions had been made. The people that were mentioned were Phillip Lynch, Neville Wran and Mick Young. Phillip Lynch, Neville Wran and Mick Young are only a tiny proportion of the number of political figures in this country against whom allegations have been made in the past. We do not have to go too far back into history to pick up others.

I will not abuse the privileges of this place by naming names, but let me just refer to the Independent Commission Against Corruption being held at the moment in New South Wales. A certain political figure from that State has been mentioned time and again during that hearing. Although that individual happens to come from the other side of politics, none of us on this side of politics immediately jumped up and demanded that that individual should stand aside. For our own cheap political reasons, we could have done that, but we held to principles.

If we move north to Queensland, we are hearing not only about a royal commission in Queensland but also about trials which have resulted in politicians from that State being incarcerated in prison for deeds that were committed. Yet the allegations were made prior to and during royal commissions. Should all of those people have been stood aside? The mere fact that some of the allegations against some politicians have stuck and people have been imprisoned does not and should not mean that every time an allegation or assumption is made about a person in public life that individual should stand aside.

Let us face it: our constituents on a weekly or daily basis make accusations against us and we, in turn, make allegations against each other across the chamber. We play with politics. We are also playing-and sometimes we forget this-with the lives and the careers of human beings. But the people who are sometimes forgotten in this whole series of allegations, assumptions and charges are the families of the individuals who are there in the spotlight. We do have to be aware of that.

In concluding, I repeat the challenge that the Prime Minister issued on 16 April, and which was repeated earlier by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, to the Opposition about principles in matters such as those being debated here: it is up to the Opposition to state publicly its principles and the principles by which it will be guided in matters such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan has very properly focused our attention upon the issue of the game of politics, the way we play politics and the way that Government and Opposition senators and members will throw the ball backwards and forwards by making allegations, counterallegations and claims about various policies and even our personalities from time to time. Brian Burke was no novice when it came to playing this game. He used to play it pretty hard.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the ways he played the game was to hire private investigators to investigate Opposition politicians. We saw this sort of practice as fairly normal, I guess, or as part of the game, in the United States during the McCarthyist era and in those sorts of places. But it is certainly unheard of in Australian politics, and definitely in Western Australian politics prior to 1983 when Burke and his mates took over control of Western Australia. He took over control of more than just the Government of Western Australia. Burke, as Senator Hill said earlier, has admitted publicly-I think on the Hinch program-that he investigated Ross Lightfoot, a former member of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly and a member of the Liberal Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He played it hard, too.

—Yes he did, but one of the things that happened to Ross was that he was investigated. Some of Mr Burke's former Cabinet colleagues, in particular, Julian Grill, said that it was quite appropriate to send someone to the corporate affairs office and to check on Ross Lightfoot's companies and so forth. But that was a cover-up. They did not just go to the corporate affairs office to look at some of the public records; they had a private investigator go into Ross Lightfoot's personal details. On the Four Corners program the other night, in a very sombre manner, Mr Lightfoot described Brian Burke's investigation. In the transcript of that program, Ross stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there were intimate details of my life going back to when I was a late teenager, to when I was in my twenties, to my business activities, from companies I had formed, from the time that I'd spent in the mounted police in South Australia, even the time that I had spent in the army, to things like my pilot's licence had run out and so on. All these things were there, and they weren't just cursory points that Smith was making. They were, in fact, quite some detail about my life.

That is the sort of investigation that this Ambassador, this former Premier, undertook of his political opponents in Western Australia. That is the sort of propriety we are looking at. As my colleagues the two previous speakers on this motion have stated, we are not talking about guilt or innocence. This is not a partisan call. It is becoming increasingly partisan because the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) refuse to act. They refuse to face their responsibilities.

It is not the Opposition's wish to make this a partisan call. These calls have been made since March 1988 when my predecessor, Senator Chaney, started raising questions in this place about the appropriateness of the appointment. These allegations, these public disclosures of information, these documents, which I listed in the Senate before Christmas, are freely available and many of them are not just mere allegations. They are serious matters of impropriety which go to the very heart of the appropriateness of Brian Burke to be appointed in the first place, and, clearly, the appropriateness of Brian Burke to remain in his position as Ambassador to Ireland. I put it to the Senate that this matter of the appointment, this matter of whether Burke should be recalled, which has been focused upon by every major daily newspaper around this nation, has become an issue because the Minister and the Prime Minister refuse to act.

It is the last thing that we in the Opposition want to occur. We do not want this to be partisan. We do not need this to be an issue. As a Western Australian, I feel-as would Senator Knowles, Senator Durack and other senators in the chamber today, I am sure-that if this issue could go away, it would be better for our home State. We are proud and loyal Western Australians and to have this focus on affairs in our home State is a matter of some concern and embarrassment. Irrespective of whether Burke was a Labor Premier, he was a former Premier of Western Australia. To have this focus on our home State does us no good. In fact, at the moment it is an embarrassment to come from Western Australia. And Burke made that take place.

I conclude my first point about responsibility by saying that it is the Minister's and the Prime Minister's responsibility to act. They have tried to buck pass the problem by asking the Ambassador to make a decision himself. That is not good enough. The Minister should have acted. It has become an international and a national issue because of their failure to act.

The partisanship question is not really a matter of partisanship between the Opposition and the Government. The partisanship question is the struggle between the factions of the Australian Labor Party. It is a struggle between Burke's mates and those on the Government side who are not his mates. Senator Walsh would have been very happy for Burke to have been stood aside back in December or November. The honourable member for Perth, Dr Charlesworth, would have been very happy. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, would have been very pleased for Burke to have been stood aside or recalled. They are all in favour of propriety in Australia's international interests and they have no friendship with this Burke character who remains the Ambassador.

Of course, on the other side we have the Ambassador's mates: the Prime Minister, Senator Richardson and other figures of the New South Wales Right, and also Senator McKiernan, who I note has left the chamber. There is a struggle between standing by one's mate versus Australia's national and international interests. That is the real struggle. I believe that Senator Hill was quite right in saying that, if this pressure were not on the Minister for Foreign Affairs, he would have acted a long time ago. He would have acted before Christmas.

Senator Knowles has gone through the matters that should have been investigated. They are not allegations. Most of the matters that I have raised in the Senate since October last year are matters on the public record. They are documents, they are statements of fact, many admitted by Burke, and they do impinge upon and raise questions about his propriety in these events. They should have been investigated by the Minister. They were not. As I said last year, the more he refuses to act, the more he refuses to investigate these matters, the more he fails to do his job and to uphold his responsibility, the more he implicates himself. He is saying, `Let's let Burke act; let's let Burke take the action'.

The Minister, in his contribution to the debate today, referred to international press coverage. He referred to the fact that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will be monitoring this. I have been monitoring this with my limited resources. Already there have been a number of articles in newspapers, such as The Times, The Independent, the Irish Times and the Sunday Telegraph, talking about Brian Burke's involvement and the cloud that hangs over him and the appropriateness of leaving him as an ambassador.

In the major Australian daily newspapers, virtually without exception, there have also been calls by the editorials for Brian Burke to be recalled. This is not a partisan issue. This is a matter where the non-partisan editors of all of the major newspapers in Australia have made their calls-the Sydney Morning Herald, the West Australian, the Australian Financial Review, the Telegraph Mirror just to name a few. The Sydney Morning Herald, one of Australia's major newspapers, has made the call as the lead on its editorial on both 6 December and 12 April-two editorials in less than six months-for Burke to be stood down.

It is an international issue. It is affecting our reputation overseas. It is not a matter for Brian Burke to make a decision on at a time when it suits him. It is a matter for the Minister and the Prime Minister to act on. This is an urgency motion. It is not-as Senator Powell called it-an opportunistic political activity. The fact is that Mr Burke has touched down in Australia today or will be touching down tomorrow and it is an appropriate time, albeit very late, for the Minister to take action. We believe that Burke will probably make his own decision and take his own action by Monday. This would totally reinforce our point that the Minister has failed to act. We call on him to act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion and I take the Senate back to the basic facts. In this case there have been no charges whatsoever laid. They are simply allegations made before a royal commission. It is not acceptable to assume, as Senator Knowles indicated, that some of the evidence that has been appearing is damaging to Ambassador Brian Burke. At one point in her speech, Senator Knowles said that these statements were made under oath. I do not think that I need to tell members of this Senate that in courts of law and in royal commissions there have been many occasions on which lies have been told under oath, that people have perjured themselves, either to defend themselves or to shift the blame onto someone else.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Connell's evidence is simply evidence before a royal commission. No charge has been laid against Ambassador Brian Burke. This Senate is not, and should never be, a court of law to decide on the innocence or otherwise of any individual in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the question.
—That is the question. I know that Senator Campbell at some time in his speech said that we are not talking about guilt and innocence.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the facts of life about the way people interpret legal procedures and guilt and innocence out in the community. It is all very well to come in here and enunciate what would appear on the face of it to be high-minded ideals, that somehow or other everyone is objective about this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—For example, Senator Campbell, like any other loyal patriot from the west, says he is only interested in protecting the good name of Western Australia. That is fine and that may be his genuine view. But does that mean that Ambassador Brian Burke has to accept that the weight of evidence given by Mr Laurie Connell before a royal commission is sufficient to force or make it incumbent on Ambassador Brian Burke to stand down?

SPEECH.PARA: More particularly, we all know that, if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) were to force Ambassador Burke to stand down, or if the Minister were to stand down Ambassador Burke, technically that is no indication of the guilt or innocence of Ambassador Burke. But we are also not babes in the woods. We know that the standing down of Brian Burke by his Minister would imply in the minds of the public, and especially in the minds of the media, a degree of guilt which would encumber Ambassador Burke before any court in this land if any charges were to be laid. It would also encumber him as he appeared before a royal commission. He would not be Ambassador Burke when he went into that royal commission to give evidence and presumably to refute the evidence already given by people like Laurie Connell; he would be Brian Burke, the man who was sufficiently worrisome in the legal process to justify being stood down by his Minister. Ambassador Burke has every entitlement to go into that royal commission as Ambassador Burke. There is no charge against him. Therefore, he has a right to be judged as a person who is innocent of any charges.

There have been many occasions in this Senate when Senator Durack, the then Attorney-General, and Senator Gareth Evans, speaking on behalf of the Attorney-General, have indicated that they will not interfere in matters that are sub judice before royal commissions, the High Court of Australia or any other court in this land. I am pleading the case today that neither this Senate nor the Minister should encumber a person with even a smidgin of guilt before he or she goes into either a royal commission or a court of law in this land.

Brian Burke as yet has had no opportunity to tell his story before the royal commission. He has had no opportunity to put his case on oath. Is the Opposition today telling us that a man who as yet has had no opportunity to put his case before a royal commission should be stood down on the presumption, based upon evidence given by Laurie Connell and others, that there is something smelly about his background? Is that sufficient for us to recall an ambassador? Does that mean that, if charges or allegations are made against a senator in a royal commission, that senator should stand down? I deny that that principle should underlie the way in which this Parliament or our foreign service should operate. If people knew that all they had to do to make a senator stand down or an ambassador return from his post was make an allegation in this place or before a royal commission, when would it end?

People will notice that I, for example, and many others on this side of the chamber have never called for the standing down of some of the Ministers in New South Wales who have been appearing before the Independent Commission Against Corruption with allegations made against them. I believe that those Ministers have a right to retain their posts until charges have been laid or the evidence is overwhelming. We have certainly never asked for those Ministers to stand down when they have not even been given their chance to reply under oath in a royal commission.

I want to make my last point about the media. Someone from the Opposition mentioned that media editors have been almost unanimous in calling for Brian Burke to stand down. Someone else mentioned what Derryn Hinch did. Heaven forbid that Derryn Hinch becomes the judge and jury of our foreign service and of people in this place! Are we going to let Derryn Hinch be the judge and jury of guilt and innocence in this place and of our foreign service? The answer is resoundingly no. I am sure it is in the heart of hearts of everyone on the other side. When do newspaper editors become the determinants of a person's guilt or innocence in this country? They try. Some of them would love to. But the answer is that while people like the members of this Government sit in this place-and my guess is many members of the Opposition-newspaper editors will not become the judge and jury in this country. Part of our role in this place is to ensure that civil liberties are protected. No matter whether one is a politician, priest or pauper, one is entitled to the same processes of justice as anyone else in this country. Because one is an ambassador does not mean that one is treated any worse than anyone else in this country. I oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief. The first question inherent in the urgency motion before us is whether a person holding public office should be stood down when allegations of impropriety are made before a royal commission. The second question is whether the integrity of our relations with other countries is such that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) should stand down an ambassador when allegations of possible impropriety are made about that ambassador before a royal commission. The third question underlying the urgency motion is whether the situation is of such a nature that it is detrimental to our democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the first question-that is to say, whether a person holding public office should be stood down when allegations of possible impropriety are made before a royal commission-if that were so, quite a lot of people may well be faced with that possibility, not only with the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters but also with another royal commission that is coming forward. I do not think that that is really appropriate. I am not sure whether that is underlying the urgency motion. More probably, what is underlying the urgency motion and what has emerged from the speeches from the Opposition side is the question of the integrity of our relations with another country, namely, Ireland, and the Holy See, to which Brian Burke is the Ambassador representing Australia.

I am not concerned about that, in so far as it relates to Ireland and the Holy See. There may be a point, if he were ambassador to some country which has not got a long history of understanding of the civilised process and the diplomatic process, but the Holy See, of all places, has probably got the longest of such understandings. I do not suppose it would be terribly fazed-not so much as to what the allegations are, but about the fact that allegations have been made to the Royal Commission in Perth.

Secondly, I am not so sure that the Irish would be terribly fazed. The Irish have a long history of understanding of what international affairs are about. I do concede that it may be a different question if he were an ambassador to some other less sophisticated country. That is just my opinion, for what it is worth.

The third question is whether this whole thing is of such a nature as to question the democracy in our country. If the Senate wants my view, I would say this: on a scale of one to 10, even if the allegations were true-and, as has been indicated, that has not been established and it is certainly premature and, in my view, unfair for us to come to a conclusion before the other side is put and the report is made-I would put that as a threat to democracy at about four. I would put the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) at about eight, and a few other organisations which are making decisions determining major issues which are not properly considered before this Parliament.

I have stood up here time and time again to indicate to the chamber that the $450,000 that the NHMRC gave to the Singer outfit to develop a philosophy, if you like to call it that, for experimentation on early human beings was given without proper examination by the people or the Parliament. Eventually, the sort of thing that is happening in Western Australia will come out into the open because somebody will trip up somebody else or tread on some toes, and the other people will blow the whistle. It always comes out into the open. I believe that, taken to its extreme, it is a certain threat to democracy, but there are other more major threats to democracy, in my view.

Finally, what I have said relates to the motion which asks for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to stand down Ambassador Burke. My comments have been directed to the question of whether Ambassador Burke should be stood down. Of course, they have not gone to the question of whether Ambassador Burke should stand down himself. In my view, that is entirely a matter for him. The question before us is whether this person holding a public office should be stood down and, in my view, that is not a motion which I would agree with.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

The speech read as follows-
The Bill proposes amendments to several Acts within the Industrial Relations portfolio.

The most significant amendments relate to the structure of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission under the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and that of the Trade Union Training Authority and its management under the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975. Amendments are also proposed to the Defence Act 1903 and the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989.
Industrial Relations Act 1988

The amendments to the Industrial Relations Act are proposed in Part 3 of the Schedule to the Bill. They result from the Government's acceptance of a report presented by a Committee of Review into the structure of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the remuneration of its members.

The review, which was announced in May 1990 when the legislative salary nexus between Presidential Members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and Judges of the Federal Court of Australia was repealed, commenced its work later in the year.

It was conducted by a Committee chaired by Mr Gerry Gleeson, former Head of the NSW Premier's Department, with the assistance of the Honourable Justice Trevor Olsson, a Judge of the Supreme Court of South Australia, and Professor Alan Fels, Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority.

The Committee was required to inquire into the categories of membership of the Commission and the structural arrangements that should apply; appropriate internal and external salary relativities; and the total remuneration package for the proposed categories of members. The Committee invited submissions from all interested parties, including the Commission, the major employer bodies, the ACTU and the State Governments, and undertook appropriate consultations. It presented its report to the Government on 1 March 1991.

The Government has accepted all of the Committee's recommendations as they provide a sound basis on which to strengthen the Commission's structure and to put it in a better position to address its increasing range of responsibilities and the wider scope of its jurisdiction.

These reforms will complement the initiatives which the Government took in framing the Industrial Relations Act to enable the Commission to exercise a broader jurisdiction. It will also facilitate the increasing co-operation between the Commission and its State counterparts, including through members of each being commissioned to hold office on both the federal and State tribunals.
I now turn to the detail of the proposals which are included in the legislation.

In line with the recommendations of the Gleeson report, it is proposed to introduce a revised structure for the Commission which will include two new levels, in addition to those of President, Deputy President and Commissioner. These new offices of Vice President and Senior Deputy President are expected to have the responsibilities described in the report and to which I will refer later. Appointees to the new positions will be required to have at least the same professional qualifications as presently apply to Deputy Presidents. The Governor-General must be satisfied, however, that, by reason of skills and experience in the field of industrial relations, a person is suitable for appointment to the office concerned.

The Vice President will, among other responsibilities, assist the President in the administration of the operations of the Commission, and is expected to have the oversight of major issues within the Commission's jurisdiction. This will assist the President who has a heavy workload under the Act.

The Vice President's administrative role will necessarily involve assisting the President with the more important matters relating to the Commission's operation, such as the establishment of Full Benches, assignments to the Commission's industry panels and the overall co-ordination of relations between the Commission and State industrial tribunals. The President's statutory ability to delegate powers will be amended to facilitate this, but the President will also be able to delegate powers to other Presidential Members where appropriate.
The working arrangements between the President and Vice President will, of course, be a matter for those office holders to settle themselves.

The Senior Deputy Presidents will have a vital role in the Commission's work. They may be expected to deal with the most difficult and responsible work of the Commission as well as having a leading role in the operation of the arrangements under which there is co-operation and co-ordination between the federal and State industrial tribunals. The report refers to the possibility of Senior Deputy Presidents holding concurrent appointments to judicial offices. At this stage, the Government has not reached any conclusions on such an initiative. Even so, that does not affect the strong justification for the new positions.

The legislation also provides for a more flexible approach to the composition of Full Benches, in line with the Committee's recommendation. It is proposed that a Full Bench be able to be established which includes one Presidential Member, rather than two as at present. It will remain the responsibility of the President to determine how a Full Bench should be constituted, having regard to the nature of the matter with which it is to deal.

The Committee raised a number of other matters. It made a detailed examination of the remuneration of members of the Commission in the light of the relevant wage fixing principles. The Committee's recommendations have formed the basis of the Government's submission to the Remuneration Tribunal which will continue to be responsible for determining remuneration for members of the Commission.

The report also recommends certain changes to the other entitlements of members. The necessary administrative action is under way to implement these recommendations. I have also referred some administrative matters mentioned in the Gleeson report relating to the functions of panels and office accommodation to the President of the Commission for his consideration. The Government strongly supports the Commission's independence and welcomes the recommendations of the Gleeson Committee which reinforce its autonomy. The legislative action now proposed will strengthen the Commission, while respecting its continued independence.
Defence Act 1903

The amendments to the Defence Act are proposed in Part 1 of the Schedule to the Bill. They will streamline the procedures of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, enabling it to deal with matters more speedily and allow more efficient use of its resources.

The current quorum for the Tribunal is two members, although, in practice, it would be rare for any matter to be dealt with by other than all three members. The amendments will allow the Chairman of the Tribunal to direct that a single member conduct its business in relation to a matter specified in the direction.

The amendments will also provide for the procedures of the Tribunal where such a direction is given. These are akin to the procedures to be followed when the Tribunal is constituted other than by a single member.

Provision will be made for review of action by a single member. The Minister, Secretary or Chief of the Defence Force will be able to seek such a review. As soon as practicable after receipt of a written notice specifying the grounds of review, the Tribunal is to reconsider the action of the single member and affirm, vary or replace it.

The amendments to the Defence Act will also supplement the existing rights of audience before the Tribunal. At present, the Commonwealth and the Defence Force Advocate have such rights. The Tribunal will be able, where appropriate, to permit some other person or body to be present during the hearing of a matter and to make submissions.

Finally, the amendments will allow the Tribunal to give effect to agreements between the Minister, on behalf of the Commonwealth, and the Chief of the Defence Force, acting on behalf of the members of the Defence Force.
Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989

The amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act are proposed in Part 2 of the Schedule to the Bill. They are of a minor drafting and technical nature, and have no policy implications.
Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975
Part 4 of the Schedule to the Bill contains the amendments proposed to the Trade Union Training Authority Act.

Over the past two years, significant structural and administrative changes to the Trade Union Training Authority (or TUTA) have been undertaken. These have included the appointment of National Industry Training Officers, who are responsible for development and implementation of training for particular industry groups, as well as measures to increase productivity and redirect resources to expand the national training effort without further call on the budget.
Legislative changes are also required. The amendments will:
- replace the 16 member National Council of Trade Union Training with an 11 member Executive Council of TUTA;
- abolish the Regional Councils for the States and Territories, but empower the Executive Council to establish Regional Advisory Councils, as required; and
- replace the positions of National Director and Director of Studies with a single position of Executive Officer.
These changes will result in the better use of TUTA's resources. They will contribute significantly to the development of the national focus in trade union training.

At the same time, it is important to note that representation of relevant interests will be enhanced. The membership of the Executive Council of TUTA, although smaller than that of the present Australian Council, will continue to represent the interests of unions, employers, the Government, and the staff of TUTA. It will now also include a community representative.

The Confederation of Australian Industry, which has traditionally represented employers on the Australian Council of TUTA, will specifically be consulted about employer representation on the Executive Council.

The abolition of the Regional Councils for the States and Territories is consistent with the national focus proposed for TUTA. But the capacity to establish Regional Advisory Councils, where this is required, will enable TUTA to deal effectively with issues which arise in particular geographical areas.
Financial Impact Statement

The financial impact of the amendments to the IR Act resulting from the Gleeson Report is not yet quantifiable, as remuneration for the new offices is yet to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. Moreover, it has not yet been determined when and how many appointments to the new offices will be made. The Bill will not have any other significant financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The purposes of the Bill are to remove from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 the exemption for superannuation and replace it with more limited exemptions, to insert in the Sex Discrimination Act a number of exemptions for certain Commonwealth and Territory legislation which is presently exempted by Regulations, and to amend the Marriage Act 1961 and the War Gratuity Act 1945 so as to remove inconsistencies with the Sex Discrimination Act.

The process which led to the first set of amendments in the Bill, dealing with superannuation, dates back to the report by the then Human Rights Commission titled ``Superannuation and Insurance and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 Part 1-Superannuation''. That report was prepared in response to a request by the then Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Gareth Evans, and was tabled in Parliament on 25 November 1986. The report was considered by the Government and it was decided that the exemption be removed and certain more limited exemptions for particular practices in superannuation be inserted into the Act. Following the Government's decision, consultations on the proposed exemptions were held with the superannuation industry, employer groups, State and Territory Governments and the ACTU.

The Government, as indicated in its National Agenda for Women, is committed to the objective of removing discrimination in superannuation on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy. The major effect of this Bill is to remove most forms of direct discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status in superannuation practices for new schemes. Where funds are unable to comply with the new obligations under the legislation, the reasonable expectations of the members will be maintained and the discriminatory fund will be allowed to continue. However, such funds will not be entitled to admit new members. Further, members of such discriminatory schemes will generally have to be given an option to obtain non-discriminatory superannuation benefits.
The proposed continuing exemptions, shortly stated, deal with the following areas:
- the inclusion in fund conditions of a provision which is based upon actuarial data upon which it is reasonable to rely;

- the current practices whereby lesser death and disability benefits are provided to members who are single, that is members who do not have a spouse or a de facto spouse, or to members who do not have a child;
- the possibly discriminatory effect of current vesting, preservation and portability arrangements in funds' conditions;
- the protection of the existing expectations of members of discriminatory schemes.

The introduction of the Bill was initially delayed pending the reappraisal by the Government of a proposed exemption which would have allowed funds to confine the provision of superannuation benefits to permanent and full-time employees. In January 1989 the Government decided not to proceed with this exemption. Following that decision a further round of consultations on the issue was held with the superannuation industry, peak employer bodies, State Governments and the National Women's Consultative Council.

The Bill was first introduced on 11 May 1989 but lapsed when elections were called. It was then amended by the deletion of proposed section 41c, which would have permitted the remaining superannuation exemptions (i.e. sections 41a and 41b) to be repealed by regulation. This provision, which was opposed by the Opposition, was not considered essential to the Bill. The Bill was re-introduced on 12 September 1990 but was withdrawn in order to make several minor technical and drafting amendments. As the Regulations providing exemptions for inconsistent Commonwealth, State and Territory laws were being reviewed at the time, the Government decided to incorporate the amendments to the superannuation exemption into a more comprehensive Bill which further limits the scope of existing exemptions under the Sex Discrimination Act.

I turn now to a brief description of the proposed limited exemptions to be inserted in the Act. The first I wish to outline are those relating to superannuation. Because, statistically, women live longer than men, the actuarial exemption covers the resulting difference in costs of providing a pension for women. Schemes will be able to continue to offer optional conversions between lump sums and pensions which differ by sex, so long as the difference is reasonably based on reliable actuarial data. As many superannuation benefits are provided via insurance this exemption is interlinked with the insurance exemption in the Sex Discrimination Act.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has released a Report on the exemption of insurance from the Sex Discrimination Act. This Report is now being considered by the Government. The need for the actuarial exemption for superannuation may need to be reviewed in light of the Government's response to the Commission's recommendations concerning the insurance exemption.

The exemption for certain superannuation benefits is designed to allow schemes to continue current practices, whereby upon a member's death or disability no benefits to or in respect of dependants are payable for a member who does not have a legal or de facto spouse or children. In the absence of this kind of exemption it may have been possible for a member who was single to succeed in a complaint of marital status discrimination. There are a number of reasons for maintaining this exemption. As the former Human Rights Commission noted in its Report, the exemption reflects the community's attitude that it is appropriate to make special provision for persons who have a spouse or who have children in the event of the death, or physical or mental incapacity of members of superannuation funds. As was noted by the Commission, to provide benefits to all dependants of members on proof of financial dependency would create difficulties both in administration and in finding a suitable objective test of ``dependency''.

In regard to the exemptions dealing with vesting, preservation and portability, the issue of discrimination arises because there is evidence that women statistically do not remain in continuous employment for the same length of time as men. Matters such as vesting, preservation and portability fall within the area of the operating standards for superannuation funds administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Regulations made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 impose a number of operating standards with which superannuation funds must comply in order to be eligible for taxation concessions. These standards require all member-financed benefits and all employer-financed benefits arising from contributions made in accordance with an industrial agreement or award to vest in full in the member. They also require certain benefits, including award superannuation and personal superannuation benefits to be preserved, generally until retirement at or after age 55. The Government announced in the 1989 Budget that the introduction of vesting and preservation standards covering all employer-financed benefits will be phased in with effect from 1 July 1995. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission is engaged in the process of consulting with the superannuation industry, employers and unions for the purposes of the detailed implementation of these improved vesting and preservation standards.

The Bill also provides in clause 6 that section 14 of the Sex Discrimination Act is to be amended to make it unlawful for a person who exercises a discretion in relation to the payment of a superannuation benefit, in respect of a member of a superannuation fund to whom the provisions of new section 41a apply, to discriminate on the grounds of sex or marital status. The purpose of this provision is to ensure that trustees, when deciding who should receive such benefits, consider the circumstances of all the potential beneficiaries rather than making their decision purely on the basis of a person's marital status. For example, it will be unlawful not to pay a death benefit to a current de facto spouse purely because of a fund policy to always pay such benefits to the current legal spouse.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill which are designed to protect the existing expectations of members in superannuation schemes. New section 41b will enable schemes which cannot or do not wish to comply with the requirements of new section 41a to continue to provide benefits for existing members, provided current members of these funds have the option to obtain non-discriminatory superannuation benefits. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may, pursuant to section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act, grant an exemption from the requirement to provide an option to current members. This will enable trustees or employers to apply for an exemption where it is clear that it would not be beneficial for current members to join a new scheme or to obtain non-discriminatory benefits.

The amendments concerning superannuation contained in this Bill should not have an impact upon Government expenditure. However, it is anticipated that all Commonwealth superannuation schemes will be amended in separate legislation to comply with the Sex Discrimination Act by the time the proposed provisions of this Bill come into effect. These further changes may affect Commonwealth expenditure.

Superannuation is a very technical area of the law and the issues of discrimination which may arise may vary from case to case and industry to industry. The former Attorney-General wrote to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner requesting that guidelines be published to clarify the application of the Bill to particular situations. In addition, where trustees or employers feel that they should be exempted from the requirements proposed in this Bill, they can apply to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for an exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act.

The Government believes that the amendments outlined above represent a significant reform. While I am informed that most schemes will be able to comply with the amendments with only minor adaptations to their existing conditions, the amendments will require schemes which have not yet modified their benefits to do so over the next two years, or to close off their membership. Further the amendments are likely to increase the opportunity for part-time employees to gain access to superannuation. This will significantly improve the opportunities for women to build up a worthwhile superannuation entitlement over their working lives. A large majority of part-time employees are women and it is clear that women tend to return from child rearing to part-time employment. Where part-time employees are performing the same duties as their full-time counterparts and the fulltime counterparts receive superannuation, it is likely that a Court would find a failure to provide access to superannuation to such part-time employees unlawfully discriminatory.

These amendments should therefore be viewed in light of the Government's commitment to increasing superannuation coverage for the Australian work force. Arbitrated superannuation awards are providing increasing superannuation coverage. These amendments will not only encourage this development and help Australia make appropriate provision for its ageing population, but the benefits which will be offered will be fairer and more equitable and in line with the Government's commitments under the National Agenda for Women.

The remainder of the amendments to be effected by this Bill concern the exemptions for inconsistent Commonwealth, State and Territory laws. The original purpose of the exemptions was to allow a period of two years from the date of commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act for the relevant governments to amend their legislation so as to remove inconsistencies with the Act. The original exemptions were due to expire on 31 July 1986 and, although the number of exemptions has decreased each year, exemptions have been continued for some legislation since then. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has expressed strong concerns about the possibility of any further renewals of the exemptions by Regulation. Following consultations with the State and Territory governments and the relevant Commonwealth Departments, the Government has decided that it is inappropriate for the practice of exemption by Regulation to continue. Consequently, it is proposed that the existing provisions of the Act concerning the power to extend exemptions by regulations i.e. section 40, subsections (2), (3) and (4), be repealed by this Bill. The current Regulations expire on 31 July this year.
After consulting the relevant Commonwealth Departments, the Government has decided to grant indefinite exemptions under subsection 40 (2) of the Act to a number of Commonwealth Acts. These are:
Sections 4 (1) and 84 (1) of the National Health Act 1953;
the Social Services Act 1980 (Norfolk Island);
the Gift Duty Assessment Act 1941;
the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936;
the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953;
the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935; and
the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax Assessment) Act 1982.

The relevant sections of the National Health Act and the Social Services Act (Norfolk Island) are discriminatory on the grounds of sex in that they mirror the discriminatory provisions that apply different ages for pension eligibility for men and women under the federal Social Security scheme. The provision of an indefinite exemption for these Acts is consistent with the existing indefinite exemption provided for the Social Security Act 1947.

The Income Tax Assessment Act uses a number of terms such as ``relative``, ``associate'' and ``dependant'' which are discriminatory on the grounds of marital status. These terms, as defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act, are used in the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax Assessment) Act. As these provisions are aimed at preventing tax avoidance and the abuse of tax concessions, the desirability of indefinitely exempting this legislation is obvious.
The Gift Duty Assessment Act only applies to gifts made before 1 July 1979. As most assessments have already been made, amendment of this Act is considered inappropriate.

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act uses the terms ``relation'' and ``dependant'' which are defined so as to be discriminatory on the grounds of marital status. The Act exempts from duty certain goods sent to or imported for the personal use of members of the Armed Forces of the United States and of Papua New Guinea or their descendants. These provisions permit Australia to comply with bilateral Agreements entered into with those countries.
The existing exemptions under section 40 (2) are to be reinserted into the Act by new subsection 40 (2).

The regulations under the Gift Duty Assessment Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Sales Tax `Exemptions and Classifications) Act are also to be given an indefinite exemption as provided for in new subsection 40 (3).

An exemption under new subsection 40 (4) is to be given to Student Assistance Schemes provided for in the Student Assistance Act 1973. The criteria for means tests and rates of payment for these student assistance schemes are discriminatory on the basis of marital status. The Government has decided to undertake a review of the discriminatory provisions of these schemes over the next three years and has limited the period of the exemption accordingly.

The Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs are currently conducting reviews of the Defence Act and the Defence Services Homes Act respectively with a view to amending the provisions of these Acts which are inconsistent with the Sex Discrimination Act. Consequently, an indefinite exemption is not required for these Acts. If these Acts are not amended before the expiration of the current Regulations, an administrative exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act may be sought from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Most of the inconsistent State and Territory laws covered by the Regulations have either been amended to remove inconsistencies with the Sex Discrimination Act or no longer have any application. Of the inconsistent legislation which remains, the necessary exemptions may be continued, on application of the relevant government to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, by the grant of an administrative exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act. In regard to the State legislation prohibiting women being employed in lead processing, it is open to employers to apply to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for an administrative exemption. Consequently, no action is required by Parliament in respect of relevant State and Territory legislation.

The amendments to the Marriage Act to be effected by this Bill remove the long-standing discrimination on the grounds of sex relating to minimum marriageable age. The Bill also proposes to make gender-neutral two provisions of the Marriage Act concerning marriages solemnised overseas.

Under the existing provisions of the Marriage Act, the marriageable age for females is 16 and the marriageable age for males is 18. The minimum age at which females and males below marriageable age can obtain court authorisation to marry a person of marriageable age is 14 and 16, respectively. The Bill provides for a common marriageable age of 18 with provision for reduction to 16 in exceptional circumstances.

The provision of a common marriageable age for females and males is a world-wide tendency. There are now at least 38 countries which prescribe a common marriageable age, with 24 of these prescribing a marriageable age of 18 years. The attached table shows these countries.
