In 1989 there were around 117 000 marriages in Australia. Of these, 1052 were of females under the age of 18 years. Further, only 13 were of females under the age of 16 years and required court authorisation to marry.

The Australian Law Reform Commission recently released Discussion Paper 46 on Multiculturalism: Family Law. The Commission set out the arguments for and against a common age of 18 years and expressed a provisional view in favour of that common age. The Discussion Paper was only issued after substantial, community-wide consultations, which included the ethnic communities, and its views are based on those consultations. The focus of the Discussion Paper is whether there should be court authorisation for marriages where a person is below 18 years and, if so, in what circumstances.

A survey of marriage counsellors, marriage educators, court counsellors and national marriage counselling representatives was conducted by my Department in 1988. 47% of 1010 persons polled responded, of whom 65% were of the view that 18 is an appropriate minimum marriageable age for males and 63% that 18 is an appropriate minimum age for females.

The Attorney-General's Department has also consulted with all other Commonwealth Departments and is satisfied that there is no Commonwealth legislation other than the Marriage Act 1961 and the Family Law Act 1975 that refers to marriageable age, that there is no other Commonwealth legislation that would be affected by the proposed amendments to marriageable age, that there are no administrative arrangements that would be adversely affected and that there are no likely difficulties that might be caused in relation to any arrangements with State or Territory governments.

The Bill also contains transitional provisions relating to marriageable age which preserves the position of females between the ages of 14 and 18 who had commenced proceedings or given notice of intention to marry in accordance with the present law.

The Bill also contains a consequential provision relating to the recognition of foreign marriages by minors where neither party is domiciled in Australia. At present the Marriage Act provides that such a marriage, that would otherwise be recognised in Australia, shall not be recognised as valid while the female party is under the age of 14 years or the male party is under the age of 16 years. Those ages are, of course, the minimum ages at which parties may presently marry with court authorisation. As the Bill raises the minimum age at which a female may marry in Australia with court authorisation to 16 years, it is consistent to apply this age to the recognition of these foreign marriages. Accordingly, the Bill provides that such a marriage shall not be recognised while either party is under 16 years of age.

The Bill further deals with discriminatory provisions relating to the solemnisation overseas of certain marriages under our Marriage Act. These provisions are very rarely used. Section 77 imposes an additional requirement on a female non-Australian; section 78 imposes an additional requirement on a male non-Australian. The Bill renders both provisions gender-neutral, but does not affect their substance.

The other Act which is currently exempted by the Regulations and to which I have not yet referred is the War Gratuity Act. The War Gratuity Act provides for the payment of a gratuity to members of the Armed Forces who served in World War II and their dependants. The Act is discriminatory on the grounds of sex and marital status in that it does not recognise de facto spouses and provides differing benefits to widows and widowers. As the financial impact if the offending provisions were to be amended is minimal, the Government has decided to amend the Act to remove the discrimination. The amendments will in no way affect existing payments and entitlements but they will extend the ambit of the Act.

The Act is also to be amended so as to be expressed in gender neutral language. Section 5 of the Act is racially discriminatory but has been impliedly repealed by section 10 of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. It was therefore in keeping with the policy of amending the War Gratuity Act to be non-discriminatory to delete section 5 from the Act. These amendments are contained in Part 4 of the Bill and its attached schedule.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991
This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to six current Bounty Acts as a consequence of the Decisions announced by the Government in its Industry Statement of 12 March 1991.
The proposed changes fall into four general categories, as follows:
i) amendments to the 3 Textile, Clothing and Footwear Bounties to accelerate the phasing down in bounty rates up to the end of each bounty on 30 June 1995;

ii) amendments to the Metal Working Machine Tools and Robots Bounty to extend the bounty for a further six years, broaden its coverage to include machine tools for working advanced metals, and introduce various new eligibility criteria;
iii) amendments to the Computer Bounty to widen its coverage to include printed circuit boards, which will be offset by a slight reduction in bounty rates over the life of the Bounty; and
iv) amendments to 5 bounties to introduce minimum annual production threshold levels before bounty may be claimed, and amendment to 1 bounty to increase the minimum claim level.
i) Amendments to the three Textile, Clothing and Footwear Bounties

The amendments to the Bounty (Bed Sheeting) Act 1977, Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Act 1981 and Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 introduce complimentary changes to assistance for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries which, when taken in concert with the amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987, will extend to the year 2000.

The bounty changes incorporated in this Bill are designed to encourage the development of a more internationally competitive Textile, Clothing and Footwear (TCF) sector which will be viable with lower levels of community support. Australian consumers stand to benefit from better products at cheaper prices. Economy wide effects will accrue from the more efficient allocation of resources.
In line with these objectives;
The Textile Yarn Bounty will be phased from 30 percent value-added on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995 and replaced with a 5 percent tariff.
The Bed Sheeting Bounty will be extended to 30 June 1995 without review but will phase down from 16 cents per square metre on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995.
The Bounty on Textile Printing will phase down to zero by 1 July 1995.

In line with the recommendations of the TCF Development Authority's review of Textile Yarn bounty administration the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 is also proposed to be amended beyond the previously mentioned phasing rate changes. The major additional change is an amendment to exclude from eligibility for bounty the beaming, warping and sizing processes which are preparatory to fabric production together with any repeat winding resulting from those processes. These activities are not genuinely involved in yarn production and their exclusion will lead to an estimated reduction in outlays of around $4 million per annum.
ii) Amendments to the Metal-Working Machine Tools and Robots Bounty

The amendments to the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act 1985 provide for the continuation of bounty assistance for local production of certain machine tools and robots from 1 July 1991 to 30 June 1997.

The current metal working machines and robots bounty commenced in 1985 and is due to expire on 30 June 1991. In its recent review on this Bounty the Bureau of Industry Economics found that the present scheme had been largely effective in meeting its objectives of helping to maintain a viable machine tool industry and encouraging industry restructuring towards high technology areas and new metal cutting technologies, including the production of robots.
The provision of assistance to the local industry by way of bounty has also enabled user industries to have access to modern equipment at world prices, as imports can enter duty free.
The availability of competitively priced, locally built equipment will make a significant contribution to improving the competitive position of our manufacturing industries.
In addition to the proposed extension of the Machine Tools Bounty, several other amendments to this scheme are proposed.

It is intended to extend the Bounty's coverage to cater for current and prospective advances in the area of processing technology for new materials (such as ceramics, polymers, and composite materials). While there is little local production at present in machine tools for the working of such advance materials, this measure should encourage tooling in such areas. Equipment of this kind designated eligible for bounty will also be duty free when imported, to benefit end-users.

To avoid distortions in production, the Bill also proposes to make eligible for bounty all equipment produced in the bountiable categories, whether sold in the domestic market or overseas. This is in line with recommendations made by the BIE to remove the current bounty restriction in the Act on some export production.

The Bill also introduces a minimum annual production threshold level before bounty may be claimed, which I will outline briefly in my general remarks under the 4th general category of amendments to bounty legislation proposed by this Bill.
iii) Amendments to the Computers Bounty

The amendments to the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 provide for the widening of the computer bounty to include local manufacture of printed circuit boards from 1 July 1991. At the same time, the tariff on imported printed circuit boards is being made `Free'.

Printed circuit boards are a strategically important component used in the manufacture of a wide range of electronic microprocessor based equipment utilised by industry sectors which include telecommunications, computer, aerospace, automotive, scientific and medical, and consumer electronics.

The tariff on printed circuit boards acts as a cost imposed on local electronic equipment manufacturers and value-added assemblers, which in turn impacts on their pricing and international competitiveness. The computer bounty is a preferable form of assistance which will help reduce the costs of locally produced and imported boards while encouraging increasing levels of international competitiveness.
iv) Amendments relating to minimum annual thresholds

The amendments which introduce minimum annual threshold levels into the bounty schemes for Machine Tools and Robots, Textile Yarns, Computers, Printed Fabrics and Bed Sheeting are intended to ensure equity across the various bounty schemes which currently do not have provisions that ensure marginal producers are ineligible for bounty payments.

The primary objective of the threshold is to encourage efficient manufacturing in those sectors by eliminating from the schemes peripheral production by firms not significantly committed to bountiable production in the respective industries.
Actual savings will be minimal but the thresholds are designed to exclude small one-off claims where administrative costs can exceed payment.
Financial Impact Statement
The potential savings for the period 1992-95 as a result of the accelerated phase down in bounty rates for the 3 Textile Yarn Bounties is $56 million, at current prices.

The proposed amendments extending the Machine Tools and Robots Bounty beyond this financial year are expected to result in an overall cost to 1 July 1997 of $38.6 million (at current prices). The bounty is estimated to cost $15 million in 1991/92 (at current prices), but will phase down to around $2 million per year by financial year 1996/97.

The amendments to the Computers Bounty to widen its coverage to include printed circuit boards as from 1 July 1992 will be accommodated as far as possible within the current budget forecasts by reducing the scheduled bounty rates by one percentage point as from the 1992/93 financial year. Total bounty outlays are therefore forecast to remain at $50.1 million in 1991/92, $49.5 million in 1992/93 and $48.7 million in 1993/94.
The threshold amendments have no financial implications, as they are directed at creating efficiencies within various industries rather than being aimed at specific cost savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the Harrison inquiry into meat industry reform in regard to processing and slaughtering. I want to begin my comments by quoting from an editorial in the Herald-Sun of 11 April. The editorial states:

I am talking about an industry which provides some $3 billion of export dollars to Australia. It is an industry which has slaughtering and processing costs some two to three times higher than our international competitors.

I particularly wish to address what has occurred in Victoria; how the Victorian Government's decision has been compromised by the unholy alliance between the Victorian Government and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU); and in particular, the alliance between Premier Kirner and Wally Curran.

One might ask why a Western Australian senator is interested in a Victorian submission. The answer is simple. It is because the Harrison inquiry will have an effect on the whole of the Australian meat industry, including the industry in my State of Western Australia. If the recommendations in fact do address our lack of competitiveness, do address the need for labour market reform, do address the problems in management and are adopted, the benefits will flow through to all States, including my own.

The Victorian Government's final submission severely compromised the ability of the Harrison inquiry to do this. I seek leave to table the following documents, which I have shown to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who is at the table: Submission to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; Inquiry into the Meat Industry 1990 by the Government of Victoria, dated July 1990; Submission to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; Inquiry into the Meat Industry 1990/91 by the Government of Victoria, dated January 1991; a memo to the Chief General Manager from Barry Rowe, Minister for Agriculture; a memo to the Minister from the Chief General Manager on the subject of `Submission to Industrial Relations Inquiry into the Meat Industry'; a memo to Acting PAEL from Michael J. Kirner, from Barry Rowe, Minister for Agriculture; a handwritten note to Judy from Terry Trusworth; and the Curran critique.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would now like to give a brief summary of some of the events that have occurred in relation to this matter. In particular, I want to refer to events that have occurred in the meat industry. The Victorian State Government, under the leadership of Premier Cain, prepared a submission to the Harrison inquiry in July 1990. That submission, which has been tabled, was endorsed by the responsible Minister and was ready to go to the inquiry. After Premier Cain stepped aside and Mrs Kirner was elected Premier, the submission to the Harrison inquiry was rewritten. This `new' submission was handed over to the Harrison inquiry in January of this year. The dates on the front pages of the two submissions-1 July 1990 and January 1991-are not the only difference. Of course, there are substantial differences or deletions in terms of the second submission.

SPEECH.PARA: Wally Curran has admitted that he `doctored' the Victorian State Government's submission to the Harrison inquiry, `helping' with the rewriting of the submission. Basically, a total of 11 pages were removed from the submission. Those pages mainly dealt with the effect of prolonged industrial disputes on the industry. As well, the final page of the `new' submission blames the meat industry's woes on employers. This was not the case in the original submission. Wally Curran wrote a critique of the original submission, singling out 17 major issues with which he disagreed. Of the 17 issues with which Mr Curran disagreed, 14 were either changed or deleted in the Government's final submission.

In October 1990 the AMIEU broke an undertaking to cease industrial action at abattoirs during the Harrison inquiry. It began action over a wage claim contained in the accord mark VI. I emphasise that 12 of 19 export meatworks have closed down in Victoria. There has been a disagreement over whose jurisdiction the dispute comes under. Victorian Premier Kirner says that she will not intervene as it is a Federal matter while Senator Cook has taken the view that it is a matter for the Industrial Relations Commission. The Federal Government will not intervene.

In the six weeks to 28 November 1990, industrial disputes had caused the loss of 3.2 million man days of work and approximately $83m in export earnings. In mid-December, the Industrial Relations Commission excluded the AMIEU from the national wage case decision as a result of its continuing industrial action. The Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia estimates that industrial action over the past 18 months has resulted in a loss of over $100m in exports.

I would like now to touch briefly on some aspects of the documents that I have tabled. The fact that a government document has been amended by a union official is of grave concern. It is even more concerning when the document in question is to go to an inquiry into the industry which the union represents. The edited submission has caused deep factional splits within the Victorian Australian Labor Party. It is also believed to be one of the reasons for Barry Rowe losing his agricultural portfolio.

Premier Kirner, in answering questions and criticisms surrounding the rewritten work, stated that the original submission was only a draft, which is clearly not correct; that there was no AMIEU involvement, which is clearly not correct; and that a serious oversight had taken place by not involving the department responsible for manufacturing and industry development.

I would like to comment on some of the documents and highlight a few of the points that have been made in them. The former Minister, Mr Rowe, sent the submission and a covering letter to former Premier Cain asking him, on behalf of the Government, to forward it to the Harrison meat inquiry. On 21 November 1990 he sent a further letter, headed `Victorian Submission to Meat Industry Inquiry', to the current Premier, which states:

In April 1990 the Australian Industrial Relations Commission initiated a national inquiry into awards and conditions in the meat processing industry. Commissioner Harrison, who is conducting the inquiry, agreed to accept submissions from parties who are not signatories to the award. Consequently the Federal government and the National Farmers Federation have lodged submissions with the inquiry.

After consultation with industry groups and following advice from the Department of Labour, my department prepared a submission which was sent to your department as the basis of a Victorian government submission.
You will be aware that export opportunities, especially in Japan and Korea, will decide the future of this industry which currently contributes some $1,100m to the State's economy.

Thus, it is important that the government deal with these issues through a range of measures, which create a more productive and cooperative industrial climate. A specific measure is to ensure that the government contribute to the inquiry.
I would be pleased if you could ensure that the submission on behalf of the Victorian government is transmitted to the meat industry inquiry.
This letter was backed up by a memo signed by the Chief General Manager, D.E. Hore, which states:
BACKGROUND

In July 1990 you forwarded to the Premier a submission to the IRC inquiry into the meat industry which was prepared by this department with benefit of comment from officers of the Department of Premier and Cabinet and the Department of Labour, the ACTU and the AMIEU.

1. I have discussed the redrafted version with the Premier's Office, and indicated that removal of the time series data on investment would present an incomplete-
I emphasise the word `incomplete'-
picture of the industry at present. The observations on employers fall into the same category.

2. As such the final version departs a great deal from the document submitted by DARA to the Premier's Office, and it is now up to those agencies supporting the final version to ensure its submission to the inquiry.
The Minister wanted no more to do with the incomplete and biased submission that the Premier's Department had provided to the AMIEU, which interfered with things.

After the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs (DARA) submission was sent to the Government a critique was prepared by the Secretary of the AMIEU, Wally Curran, who proposed 19 recommendations to be included in the Government submission to the Harrison inquiry. After examining that critique, the original submission prepared by the former Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs and DARA was reworked and that reworked submission went to the meat inquiry. I can advise the Senate that 13 of the 19 recommendations were taken on board and included in the Government's submission.
On 19 March the Leader of the National Party in Victoria asked the Premier who the Government consulted with on the submission. She replied:
I have made it clear that there was consultation on the meat industry with the Victorian Farmers Federation . . .

The Premier said that consultation had occurred with the Federation, but I have with me a letter of 15 March 1991 signed by the President of the Victorian Farmers Federation, Mr Arbuthnot, in which, in part, he said:
I have had no consultation and, to my knowledge, neither has anyone else in the Victorian Farmers Federation on the Victorian government's submission to the Harrison inquiry.

MATFA was never given the opportunity of having input into any government submission to the inquiry. MATFA was certainly not consulted on the contents.

I outline the differences between the submission, which was originally prepared in July 1990, and the final submission that went to the Harrison meat inquiry. The original document contained 36 pages, but the submission presented to the inquiry was a 25-page document. Omitted from the original submission were: references to statistical data on the Victorian industry and comparison with the Queensland and New South Wales industries; the commissioned report of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs on the value-adding opportunities for agriculture-specifically cost structures in Victoria's meat processing sector-and references to the Victorian Government offering assistance to the Commission to advance the development of industrial harmony in the meat processing industry. I emphasise that that was in Victoria alone; it does not include the Queensland, Victorian or Western Australian figures.

Today I have set out to demonstrate how the inquiry process into the meat industry has been sabotaged by the unholy alliance between Premier Kirner and Wally Curran. It is a very sad occurrence because the meat industry is a very important industry to Australia. The intention in establishing the Harrison inquiry, which did a world tour, was to address the problems which exist in the meat industry. They are not problems which are confined to Victoria; they extend to all States in Australia. The fact is that we have a State government in this country which is not revealing the full picture with regard to the situation which exists in that State. It is, indeed, a very sad day for that industry and I think it is a very sad day for the political process in this country.

In fact, these documents and what has occurred demonstrate quite clearly that we have a subservient Premier and an industrial bandit running the submissions from the Victorian Government into the meat industry inquiry-the Harrison inquiry. That would be fine if it were just a Victorian problem. But it is not just a Victorian problem; it is an Australian problem. It has serious implications for the future of the meat industry. It demonstrates the incredible subservience of the Victorian Government to the AMIEU. It will affect all abattoirs, processors, and of course producers, who are the ones who sit at the bottom end of the line. They have to take what they are given.

It is a disgraceful episode in the inquiry process in this country and I throw the challenge to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, to assure this Senate that the statistical data on what has occurred in the meat industry is placed before the Harrison inquiry. As I outlined earlier, the Federal Government was given the right to put evidence before the inquiry.

The inquiry should be told the total story officially and formally. It should be told that the continuing guerilla tactics which have been adopted by the AMIEU have directly cost the meat industry about $150m and, of course, there are other aspects involved in the cost. In conclusion, I once again quote from an article in the Sun-Herald, which stated:
Certainly, if it can be established beyond doubt that the Government bowed to union pressure to make amendments favourable to the union, it is a very serious matter indeed.
The Harrison inquiry has been compromised and undermined. It is indeed a serious matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity today to address a few remarks to the Federal Government's policy directions in the area of languages. These remarks have been motivated by my reading of the recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Words at Work: A report on literacy needs in the workplace and also the Government's recently released Green Paper entitled The Language of Australia: Discussion Paper on an Australian Literacy and Language Policy for the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Australian Democrats welcome the March 1991 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee and we note that key recommendations of that report include the development of an adult literacy strategy and English language and literacy programs for all migrants. The report submits that it is the responsibility of government to ensure that all people leaving school or entering the work force are literate.

The Democrats support the development of a coordinated long term national literacy strategy. Literacy in English allows citizens to become effective and fulfilled members of society. It has been estimated that between one and two million adults in Australia cannot accomplish everyday reading and writing tasks. Other research shows that one in seven workers has insufficient literacy in English to cope with the basic safety and performance requirements of his or her job.

The Federal Government's Green Paper presents some good ideas and a commitment to improving literacy in English in the Australian community. However, that document is far too limited as a basis for future directions in a national languages and literacy policy. I suggest that it is even limited by its very title, which I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is Language of Australia.

The Green Paper tries to separate literacy from language and to restrict literacy to English only. It downplays the importance of language maintenance and ignores the provision of language services, including the needs of the deaf community. It overlooks the value of bilingualism to both individuals and the community-the fact, which is supported by evidence in the Australian context, that languages other than English support the learning of English and that literacy in one language supports literacy in another.

English literacy has always been a top priority of national languages and literacy policy. English for all, including literacy, is the first principle of the Government's current internationally acclaimed national policy on languages. There are three other basic principles which the Government must continue to support. These are support for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island languages; a language other than English for all; and equitable language services.

It is disappointing but not surprising that the thrust of the Government's changing policy in this area is oriented towards the labour market. English literacy is therefore seen as an economic resource in terms of work force participation and productivity. We condemn the statements made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on 20 March 1991 in an address to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Conference on Education and Cultural and Linguistic Pluralism. Mr Dawkins told the international delegation at that conference that Australia is a monolingual nation and that new training opportunities, including basic health and safety instruction, will be available only in English.

One of the Australian delegates to that OECD conference, Doctor Helen Andreoni, remarked at a follow-up conference on 23 March 1991-which was attended by many of the international delegates who had been at the OECD conference-that she was appalled and ashamed of the Minister's statements. Another of the many critics of the apparent shift in policy in this area, as evidenced by the Green Paper, is senior lecturer at the La Trobe University, Ms Helen Moore. In her January 1991 paper Teaching English to speakers of other languages: an Australian Perspective she states very strongly:

The Green Paper represents a significant step backwards . . . multiculturalism is a dead duck, not because it is being replaced by anything that builds from what we have learned here, but because the current agenda has no place for deviation from economic assimilation.

The Green Paper should go down in history in the company of the White Australia Policy. It is narrower in its view of Australian life. Remnants of the latter Policy's fear of difference are present in the Paper. The Green Paper is positively malign.

Mr Dawkins has also described the national policy on languages as `a bit of a dog's breakfast'. The expression is obviously not a very literary turn of phrase. The House of Representatives Committee report stated that the cost and impact of low literacy in the workplace included worker safety, such as the inability to heed warning signs or to handle dangerous chemicals.

Workers from non-English speaking backgrounds are overrepresented in some of Australia's most hazardous industries. By refusing to provide communication of even basic health and safety instructions in languages other than English, the Government is contributing to serious industrial accidents. This is a dangerous and discriminatory attitude.

The Democrats fully support urgent attention to the English language and literacy needs of all Australians, adults and children. We also support the maintenance and learning of other languages and the equitable and widespread provision of language services.

There are two essential needs in the area of languages and literacy policy: firstly, programs must be supported on a recurrent funding basis simply for stability and planning to be possible; and, secondly, learner pathways must be developed. For instance, there are currently no pathways for people who leave the adult migrant education program. Having finished that program, which only takes learners to survival level English, there is no further pathway to follow. This Government should provide such a pathway. Overall, the Government must reaffirm its commitment to the principles and spirit of the current national policy on languages and the national agenda for a multicultural Australia. This is not being done by Minister Dawkins.

The Democrats believe that the national policy on languages and the May 1990 Report on the National Policy on Languages must be used as a basis for the forthcoming White Paper. In a previous notice of motion I said that Australia should be recognised as a multicultural and multilingual nation, that English is the common and national language and that community languages are an intellectual, cultural, social and economic resource of the people and of the nation as a whole.

We appeal to the Government to reject the Dawkins world view of everything in terms of perceived economic benefit, including, under his portfolio, the overseas students fiasco and his amalgamations mania. Instead, this Government must continue to acknowledge and increasingly support the rich diversity of languages in our society.

SUBMISSION FOR THE EXPANSION OF THE NATIONAL PRICES NETWORK
INTRODUCTION
The operating costs of the expanding National Prices Network (NPN) are far in excess of allocated funds.
Without further funds, success in achieving its aims is doubtful.
Through Price Watch activities, AFCO and the APSF have been encouraged to continue their efforts to provide a community service by groups that most benefit by that service.
AIMS AND OBJECTIVES
The National Prices Network aims to provide local communities with price information on shopping choices:
* by forming groups of volunteers to monitor prices regularly;

The NPN's objective is to expand prices monitoring or action groups in all metropolitan centres, major regional centres and isolated rural areas.
PRESENT DEVELOPMENTS

Between 350 and 400 stores are regularly surveyed across Australia, by volunteers of all ages and walks of life. The Network is currently expanding into many regional areas of NSW, Victoria and SA. Volunteers are provided with a ``Basket of goods list'' for survey and results returned to NPN for analysis.
The BASKET of goods for survey has recently been reviewed and tailored to state availability of grocery items.

The NPN's computer operations were decentralised a year ago as a result of the volume of data requiring analysis. Installation of the Network's computer facilities in regional offices has been slow and there have been problems with staff training. Communication links between Network ``hierarchy'' and Price Watch volunteers is sometimes poor and erratic.

In establishing a decentralised NPN, it was anticipated that the analysis of data could be more specific to each state. While a certain degree of flexibility may be achieved, with regard to data analysis, it is at the expense of the efficiency of the operation.
Staff at state levels as a result, have extra duties and do not have enough time to manage their new roles effectively. Nor do they have sufficient resources to pursue the new functions.

Volunteers are the basis of the functioning and the success of the NPN. Volunteers can be lost through mishandling. Vital price information can be missed because the line of communication is not followed through nor is the community getting the benefit it was promised in joining the NPN.
All these outcomes are more likely now, than has been in the past because the funds allocated to the operation of the NPN have not grown at the same rate as the workload.
PROPOSAL TO UPGRADE THE NATIONAL PRICES NETWORK
AFCO and the APSF propose this plan to upgrade the National Price Network:
* changes to Organisation of the NPN;
* changes to Operations (Profile);
* changes to Network Resourcing;
Changes to Organisation of the NPN

It is proposed that the NPN be established as a separate incorporated body with membership open to any organisation sympathetic to its aims. It is expected that membership would include AFCO, APSF, ACOSS, the National Council of Women, Prices Action Groups themselves and perhaps industry groups such as the Australian Supermarket Institute (ASI).

The proposal includes changing the role of the present Co-ordinating Committee to one more like a Board of Directors. Membership of the Board would be elected by the NPN membership. The proposal also includes incorporation of the NPN thus funding would be directly to NPN rather than via AFCO and APSF.

The Board would be responsible for the operation of the NPN with an expanded administrative staff including a full time economist, a full time administrator, and a full time development officer. Part time staff would include at the central office, a supporting clerical officer, and at state level, officers whose responsibilities include ensuring that the agreed functions of the NPN are met; possibly by means of a contractual agreement. All employees would be responsible to the NPN Board.
Changes to Operations

AFCO and the APSF see in an expanded NPN, a prices advocacy role. This role would be taken by an economist whose knowledge and training would allow a balanced view of market forces and prices issues. This person would be the principal advocate of the Network. A new advocacy role would involve representation of consumer views before Prices Surveillance Authority inquiries and other inquiries into price issues or price related issues.
This position would carry the primary media profile for the Network.
Changes to Network Resourcing

The proposal including centralising the administration of the National Prices Network; volunteer database files; ensuring that agreed functions are met with regard to the services promised to local communities; and ensuring that all volunteers are serviced properly.
At present, some of these functions are being met some of the time. AFCO and the APSF are committed to providing this community service at the highest professional level.

The Network would be administered centrally. The administrator would be responsible for ensuring the major functions (eg sending and collecting of survey forms, processing and sending results in accordance with survey schedules, distributing a monthly newsletter, maintaining volunteer database, management of finances, keeping of accounts) are achieved.

A development officer would be responsible for expanding Network operations in major regional, rural and metropolitan areas; assisting in problem solving in any locality; travelling to speak to community groups and assisting with media liaison.
BUDGET PROPOSED TO EXPAND THE
NATIONAL PRICES NETWORK

To support these changes, a considerable upgrading of funds is needed. A budget proposal is attached. At present many costs involved in operating the Network are borne by Members of Parliament in their general office expenses, for example postage, stationery and photocopying. Additionally there are the costs of extra computer equipment and part time staff to assist, paid in part by the Department of Administrative Services. This proposal transfers these costs to an independent organisation.
CONCLUSION
Most of the Network objectives are only just being achieved through the dedicated efforts of Members of Parliament, their staff and volunteers.
For the continued success of the NPN, it is essential that:
1. more funds are allocated;
2. more staff be trained, and utilised;
3. an alternative structure be implemented.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Why did the Government institute generous arrangements under recent legislation permitting taxpayers to retain the tax exempt status of their sole or principal place of residence for unlimited periods of absence, instead of the former four year maximum, provided the dwelling is not used to produce income, and extending the exemption from the former four years to six years if the residence is used for income producing purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In response to representations, the Government reviewed the temporary absence provisions which gave an exemption period of four years and required the taxpayer to reoccupy the dwelling after a period of absence. The Government considered these provisions may have been too restrictive, and the changes announced in the 1990-91 Budget were designed to extend flexibility in the application of the principal residence exemption to ensure legitimate temporary absentees were not disadvantaged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 14 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) If the Government abolishes the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, as one of the options proposed by the Government's review into Broadcasting Laws suggests, will Section 103 be retained so that members of the religious community retain access to the media.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The review of broadcasting regulation has been directed to undertake a comprehensive examination of its approach to broadcasting regulation against an agenda of seven key issues: objectives, planning, new and emerging services, ownership and control, licensing, standards and the role of the regulatory agency.

There will continue to be a requirement for an independent statutory body to carry out necessary regulatory functions. If the Government does restructure the regulatory authority, it would be sensible to base this on the established Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, with modifications to reflect any changed role and functions.

The Government is aware of the religious community's concern to have access to radio and television, and options for giving effect to this along the lines of Section 103 of the present Broadcasting Act, are being considered.

Draft legislation is being prepared as a basis for wider consideration of the regulatory reforms. It is proposed to make an exposure draft of the legislation available for consultation with interested parties prior to its finalisation. It is planned to introduce it in the 1991 Budget Sittings.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Program for Deaf or Blind Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What programs are available for people who are: (a) deaf; (b) blind and deaf or severely hearing-impaired; and (c) blind or severely visually impaired.

(2) What department(s) is/are administering these programs, with particular emphasis on: (a) pre-school education; (b) elementary and further education; (c) recreation and sport; (d) vocational training; (e) accommodation; and (f) employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Within my Department, the following programs are available for people with sensory impairments:

1(a)-The National Acoustic Laboratories-Hearing Services Program provides free hearing rehabilitation services, including assessment, selection and fitting of hearing aids and devices, counselling, ongoing aftercare and maintenance of the devices to eligible clients. Eligible clients include:
* anyone under 21 years of age;
* Department of Social Security pensioners and their with a health benefits card;
* Department of Veteran's Affairs pensioners; and
* members of the Defence Forces.
Services are provided through a network of forty five permanently staffed hearing centres and sixty five visiting centres across Australia.
1(a) (b) &(c)-The Disability Services Program and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service provide programs for people in all the groups listed.

People with sensory disabilities which are permanent or likely to be permanent and result in a substantially reduced capacity for the person's communication, learning or mobility, are eligible to access any of the 1,700 support services funded by the Disability Services Program under Part II of the Disability Services Act.

The range of support services offered are designed to meet the needs of individuals with disabilities with respect to their accommodation and employment prospects and participation in the community. An example of a service designed specifically for people with hearing impairments is the Australian Caption Centre which is provided with funding to subtitle videos and videoed television programs and the Late Edition ABC National News. These services will provide people with hearing impairments with access, for the first time, to a daily news program and other programs broadcast on television.
Services relevant to people with sensory disabilities include orientation and mobility, and print disability services funded under the Act:

* print disability services aim to assist people who cannot use reading materials in standard print by altering the format of the material to make it more accessible, for example in braille, audio or large print formats. There are currently thirteen print disability services funded under the Act; and

* orientation and mobility training aims to assist people with vision impairments to travel safely and independently. A review of orientation and mobility services in 1989 found that some 4,000 people received some form of orientation and mobility training.

The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) provides individually tailored vocational and social rehabilitation programs to people with disabilities arising from sensory, psychiatric, physical and intellectual impairments. In the 1989-90 financial year, CRS assisted 649 clients who had either hearing or vision impairment as their primary disability.
CRS programs address individual needs arising from disability and also include vocational training components such as work experience placements and formal courses to increase vocational skills.
(2)-My department administers programs for people with disabilities which focus on (c) some recreation (d) vocational training, (e) accommodation and (f) employment.
I am unable to comment on the functions of other Departments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 20 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was it confirmed in the document `Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme', Kinhill Stearns, 1985, p44 that `all previous studies rejected the addition of runway capacity to the airport because it was not cost effective for the additional aircraft movements and may make the airport difficult to plan.'
(2) Did it also confirm that further increases in runway capacity would be provided for at the second Sydney airport, not at the Kingsford Smith Airport for these reasons.
(3) How does the present study, the draft Environmental Impact Statement, differ from `all previous studies'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme Draft Environmental Impact Statement states ``The results of previous studies by the Department of Aviation and of the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Study, although preliminary, indicate that development of a closely spaced parallel runway is physically possible at Kingsford Smith Airport''.

Elsewhere the document states ``Previous studies have investigated the possibility of increasing runway capacity at Kingsford Smith Airport by constructing an additional runway parallel to the existing north/south runway. Such a proposal is physically possible, although insufficient work has been undertaken to enable the associated facility requirements and environmental impacts to be established.''

(2) No. The document stated that ``Various alternatives are available to the Commonwealth Government to ensure that airport capacity is available to meet future needs. In seeking to reserve a second airport site at this time, the Commonwealth Government has indicated its belief that the major increase in capacity in the long term should be catered for at a second airport''.
The document also stated that ``The alternative to this policy would be to:
* take no action and allow congestion at Kingsford Smith Airport to rise;
* regulate traffic flow at Kingsford Smith Airport through the pricing of landing rights at peak periods or the allocation of quotas for landing rights at these periods;
* construct an additional runway at Kingsford Smith Airport.''
(3) The Draft EIS for the proposed third runway at Sydney Airport differs from previous studies in the following way:
* it considers a medium-spaced runway parallel to the existing north-south runway
* it provides detailed information on the environmental impacts of such a proposal; and
* based upon the Sydney Airport Draft Planning Strategy, it indicates how the associated airport facility requirements could be provided.

The Draft EIS for the proposed third runway confirms the long term need for a second airport but goes further than the Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme EIS by analysing when a second airport is expected to be commercially viable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Are hepatitis B inoculations generally available upon request; if so, is the cost covered by Medicare.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The rendering of any medical service by a medical practitioner on a patient is a matter to be determined by the practitioner based on his/her professional judgement of the patient's condition.

Insofar as Medicare is concerned, provided the professional service rendered is a medical examination or test that is reasonably required for the management of the patient's medical condition, Medicare benefits would be payable. While there is no specific item(s) in the Medicare Benefits Schedule covering inoculations, such as hepatitis B, the rendering of such a service by a medical practitioner would attract Medicare benefits on an attendance basis.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Australian Airlines and Qantas

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 13 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the timetable for the sale or partial sale of Australian Airlines and Qantas.
(2) How much revenue does the Government expect to raise from each of these sales.
(3) What will be the method of sale of these assets.

(4) What role, if any, will the board of directors and management of the companies have in: (a) the decision on the method of sale; (b) the carrying out of the sale; (c) the decisions on the pricing and expected proceeds of the sale; and (d) the decisions on the timing of the sale.
(5) What role will the Assets Sales Task Force and the Department of Transport and Communications (and their respective Ministers) have in these sales.
(6) Which department (and which Minister) will have the overriding say on the sale proposals, and which will oversee the actual sale.
(7) Has any consideration been given to the superannuation arrangements of the employees of the two airlines following the sale; if so, what arrangements have been, or will be, made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government will be deciding shortly on the overall strategy to be adopted for the sale of Australian Airlines and the partial sale of Qantas. The sequencing of the two sales and the timing of the commencement of the sales will be integral to that strategy.

(2) For obvious reasons, the Government does not publicly discuss the amount it expects to receive from any prospective asset sales. To do so could seriously prejudice the achievement of maximum sales proceeds.
(3) See response to question (1).
(4) See response to question (1).

(5) The Minister for Finance will be responsible for controlling all aspects of these sales. The Task Force on Asset Sales will be advising the Minister for Finance on all aspects of the sales processes and will be responsible for managing and/or coordinating the inputs from various sources.
(6) See response to question (5).
(7) Yes.

In the case of Qantas, the existing superannuation arrangements will remain unchanged as the airline has always operated its own superannuation scheme. Partial sale should not affect these arrangements.

In the case of Australian Airlines, the sale will not affect the superannuation arrangements of those employees who are members of the various schemes operated by the airline. Those employees who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) will cease to be ``eligible employees'' for purposes of that scheme upon sale by the Commonwealth of a controlling interest in that airline. Those employees will have a range of options available to them, including transferring to the Australian Airlines' superannuation scheme or taking advantage of the deferred benefit option available under the CSS.
